title: Data visualization I
text:
The grammar of graphics

Graphs have an internal logic, or grammar that connects data to visuals


Data = variables in a dataset


Aesthetic = visual property of a graph (position, shape, color, etc.)


Geometry = representation of an aesthetic (point, line, text, etc.)

üö® Your turn üö®

Make a plot of presidential election results using the elections_historic dataset
% of popular vote (x-axis, popular_pct) and % of electoral college vote (y-axis, ec_pct)
map the winner‚Äôs party to the color aesthetic, whether or not president served two terms to shape, and add labels to each point (use winner_label)

title: Data visualization I
text:
US Presidents


Code
# libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(socviz)
library(ggrepel)

# plot
ggplot(elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct, label = winner_label,
    color = win_party, shape = two_term, label = winner_label)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5,
    size = 1.4, color = "gray80") + geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, size = 1.4, color = "gray80") +
    geom_point() + geom_text_repel() + labs(x = "Percent of popular vote", y = "Percent of Electoral College vote",
    title = "Presidential Elections: Popular & Electoral College Margins", subtitle = "1824-2016",
    color = NULL, size = NULL) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
    scale_color_manual(values = c(yellow, red, blue, "gray")) + theme(legend.position = "none")



You are not responsible for this fancy graph

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
Three scenarios
Three scenarios for the results: same effect size, different 95% CIs

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
How much should we worry?



Small range: great! Effect is precise; ads are worth it!
Big range: OK-ish! Effect could be tiny, or huge; are the ads worth it? At least we know they help (positive)
Crosses zero: awful! Ads could work (+), they could do nothing (0), or they could be counterproductive (-)

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
Crossing zero: the worst scenario
When the 95% CI crosses zero we are so uncertain we are unsure whether effect is positive, zero, or negative

Researchers worry so much about this that it is conventional to report whether the 95% CI of an effect estimate crosses zero


When a 95% CI for an estimate doesn‚Äôt cross zero, we say that the estimate is statistically significant


If the 95% CI crosses zero, the estimate is not statistically significant

title: Hypothesis testing
text: Statistical significance

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
Hypothesis testing



Statistical significance is at the center of hypothesis testing
Researcher wants to decide between two possibilities:

null hypothesis (\(H_0\)): the ad has no effect on turnout
alternative hypothesis (\(H_a\)): the ad has some effect on turnout

A statistically significant estimate rejects the null
Remember this is all about sampling uncertainty, not causality!

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
Arbitrary?

You could have an estimate with a 95% CI that barely escapes crossing zero, and call that statistically significant
And another estimate with a 95% CI that barely crosses zero, and call that not statistically significant
That‚Äôs pretty arbitrary!
And it all hinges on the size of the confidence interval
if we made a 98% CI, or a 95.1% CI, we might conclude different things are and aren‚Äôt significant
The 95% CI is a convention; where does it come from?

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
The arbitrary nature of ‚Äúsignificance testing‚Äù
Fisher (1925), who came up with it, says:

It is convenient to take this point [95% CI] as a limit in judging whether [an effect] is to be considered significant or not. (Fisher 1925)


But that other options are plausible:

If one in twenty [95% CI] does not seem high enough odds, we may, if we prefer it, draw the line at one in fifty [98% CI]‚Ä¶ or one in a hundred [99% CI]‚Ä¶Personally, the writer prefers‚Ä¶[95% CI] (Fisher 1926)


95% = one in twenty

title: Hypothesis testing
text:
The significance testing controversy



So arbitrary; why make this binary distinction?
Sometimes we have to make the call:

when is a baby‚Äôs temperature so high that you should give them medicine?
100.4 is a useful (arbitrary) threshold for action

This is a huge topic of debate in social science, other proposals we can‚Äôt cover:

redefining how we think about probability
focusing on estimate sizes
focusing on likely range of estimates

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Why are we uncertain?



We don‚Äôt have all the data we care about
We have a sample, such as a survey, or a poll, of a population
Problem each sample will look different, and give us a different answer to the question we are trying to answer







Sample locations in Guatemala

title: Uncertainty I
text:
What‚Äôs going on here? terminology






Term
Meaning
Example




Population
All of the instances of the thing we care about
American adults


Population parameter
The thing about the population we want to know
Average number of kids among American adults


Sample
A subset of the population
A survey


Sample estimate
Our estimate of the population parameter
Average number of kids in survey

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Boring example: kids
How many children does the average American adult have?

We can get the exact answer, since there are only 2,867 Americans, and they‚Äôre all in our data:

gss_sm %>% 
  summarise(avg_kids = mean(childs, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_kids
     <dbl>
1     1.85


The true average number of children in the US is 1.85 (Population parameter)

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Sampling
Now imagine that instead of having data on every American, we only have a sample of 10 Americans

Why do we have a sample? Because interviewing every American is prohibitively costly


Same way a poll works: a sample to estimate American public opinion

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Sampling
We can pick one sample of 10 people from gss_sm using the rep_sample_n() function from moderndive:


gss_sm %>% rep_sample_n(size = 10, reps = 1)

# A tibble: 10 √ó 33

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Sample estimate
We can then calculate the average number of kids among that sample of 10 people

gss_sm %>% rep_sample_n(size = 10, reps = 1) %>% 
  summarise(avg_kids = mean(childs, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
  replicate avg_kids
      <int>    <dbl>
1         1      2.5


this is our sample estimate of the population parameter

Notice that it does not equal the true population parameter (1.87)

title: Uncertainty I
text:
The trouble with samples
Problem: each sample will give you a different estimate. Instead of taking 1 sample of size 10, let‚Äôs take 1,000 samples of size 10:


kids_10 = gss_sm %>% rep_sample_n(size = 10, reps = 1000) %>% 
  summarise(avg_kids = mean(childs, na.rm = TRUE))
kids_10

title: Uncertainty I
text:
The trouble with samples
Across 1,000 samples of 10 people each, the estimated average number of kids can vary between 0.4 and 4!! Remember, the true average is 1.85

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Wrong effect estimates
Many of the effects we estimate below are even negative! This is the opposite of the population parameter (0.087)

title: Uncertainty I
text:
The solution



So how do we know if our sample estimate is close to the population parameter?
Turns out that if a sample is random, representative, and large‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶then the LAW OF LARGE NUMBERS tells us that‚Ä¶
the sample estimate will be pretty close to the population parameter

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Law of large numbers
With a small sample, estimates can vary a lot:

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Law of large numbers
As the sample size (N) increases, estimates begin to converge:

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Law of large numbers
They become more concentrated around the population average‚Ä¶

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Law of large numbers
And eventually it becomes very unlikely the sample estimate is way off

title: Uncertainty I
section: This works for regression estimates, too
text:
This works for regression estimates, too
Regression estimates also become more precise as sample size increases:

title: Uncertainty I
text:
What‚Äôs going on?
The larger our sample, the less likely it is that our estimate (average number of kids, the effect of sex on vote choice, etc.) is way off

This is because as sample size increases, sample estimates tend to converge on the population parameter


Next time = we‚Äôll see how to quantify uncertainty based on this tendency


Intuitive = the more data we have, the less uncertain we should feel


But this only works if we have a good sample

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Good and bad samples


There are good and bad samples in the world
Good sample representative of the population and unbiased
Bad sample the opposite of a good sample
What does this mean?






Good samples

title: Uncertainty I
text:
When sampling goes wrong
Imagine that in our quest to find out how many kids the average American has, we do telephone surveys

Younger people are less likely to have a landline than older people, so few young people make it onto our survey


what happens to our estimate?

title: Uncertainty I
text:
When sampling goes wrong
We can simulate this by again pretending gss_sm is the whole of the US

Let‚Äôs imagine the extreme scenario where no one under 25 makes it into the survey:

gss_sm %>% 
  filter(age >= 25) %>%
  rep_sample_n(size = 10, reps = 1000) %>% 
  summarise(avg_kids = mean(childs, na.rm = TRUE))

I‚Äôve filtered out all people in gss_sm under 25 so they cannot be sampled

title: Uncertainty I
text: When sampling goes wrong

title: Uncertainty I
text:
When sampling goes wrong
As sample size increases, variability of estimates will still decrease

title: Uncertainty I
text:
When sampling goes wrong
But estimates will be biased, regardless of sample size

title: Uncertainty I
text:
What‚Äôs going on?
The sample is not representative of the population (the young people are missing)

This biases our estimate of the population parameter


Randomness is key = everyone needs a similar chance of ending up in the sample


When young people don‚Äôt have land-lines, not everyone has a similar chance of ending up in the sample

title: Uncertainty I
text: A big problem!

title: Uncertainty I
text:
üö® Your turn: bias the polls üö®
Using the gss_abortion data again, imagine you are an evil pollster:

Think about who you would have to exclude from the data to create estimates that benefit the pro-choice and pro-life side of the abortion debate.
Show that even as the sample size increases and estimate variability decreases, we still get biased results.

title: Uncertainty I
text:
Key takeaways



We worry that each sample will give us a different answer, and some answers will be very wrong
The tendency for sample estimates to approach the population parameter as sample size increases (the law of large numbers) saves us
But it all depends on whether we have a random, representative (good) sample; no amount of data in the world will correct for sampling bias

title: DAGs II
text:
Do waffles cause divorce?
Remember, we have strong reason to believe the South is confounding the relationship between Waffle Houses and divorce rates:


Speak about true effects and null effects

title: DAGs II
text:
We‚Äôve already done it
One way to adjust/control for backdoor paths is with multiple regression:

In general: \(Y = \alpha + \beta_1X_1 + \beta_2X_2 + \dots\)


In this case: \(Y = \alpha + \beta_1Waffles + \beta_2South\)


In multiple regression, coefficients (\(\beta_i\)) are different: they describe the relationship between X1 and Y, after adjusting for the X2, X3, X4, etc.

title: DAGs II
section: What does it mean to control?
text:
What does it mean to control?


\(Y = \alpha + \beta_1Waffles + \beta_2South\)
Three ways of thinking about \(\color{red}{\beta_1}\) here:

The relationship between Waffles and Divorce, controlling for the South
The relationship between Waffles and Divorce that cannot be explained by the South
The relationship between Waffles and Divorce, comparing among similar states (South vs.¬†South, North vs.¬†North)

title: DAGs II
text:
Comparing models
Let‚Äôs fit two models of the effect of GDP on life expectancy, one with controls and one without:

no_controls = lm(lifeExp ~ gdpPercap, data = gap)
controls = lm(lifeExp ~ gdpPercap + pop + year, data = gap)


Population and year might be forks here: they affect both economic activity and life expectancy








Note


I‚Äôve re-scaled gdp (10,000s) and population (millions)

title: DAGs II
text:
The regression table
We can compare models using a regression table;
many different functions, we‚Äôll use huxreg() from the huxtable package


huxreg("No controls" = no_controls, "With controls" = controls)







Note


Format: huxreg("label for model 1" = model_1, "label for model 2" = model_2, ...)

Model 1 has no controls: just the relationship between GDP and life expectancy
Model 2 controls/adjusts for: population and year

title: DAGs II
section: Does this actually work? Back to the waffles
text:
Does this actually work? Back to the waffles
These are examples with real data, where we can‚Äôt know for sure if our controls are doing what we think

Only way to know for sure is with made-up data, where we know the effects ex ante:



fake = tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
              waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10 * south,
              divorce = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 2) + 8 * south)

title: DAGs II
text:
Controlling for the South
Fit a naive model without controls, and the correct one controlling for the South:

naive_waffles = lm(divorce ~ waffle, data = fake)
control_waffles = lm(divorce ~ waffle + south, data = fake)

title: DAGs II
text:
The results
Perfect! Naive model is confounded; but controlling for the South, we get pretty close to the truth (0 effect)

title: DAGs II
text:
What‚Äôs going on?

In our made-up world, if we control for the South we can get back the uncounfounded estimate of Divorce ~ Waffles


But what‚Äôs lm() doing under-the-hood that makes this possible?

title: DAGs II
text:
What‚Äôs going on?



lm() is estimating \(South \rightarrow Divorce\) and \(South \rightarrow Waffles\)
it is then subtracting out or removing the effect of South on Divorce and Waffles
what‚Äôs left is the relationship between Waffles and Divorce, adjusting for the influence of the South on each

title: DAGs II
text:
Visualizing controlling for the South
This is the confounded relationship between waffles and divorce (zoomed out)

title: DAGs II
text:
Add the south
We can see what we already know: states in the South tend to have more divorce, and more waffles

title: DAGs II
text:
Effect of south on divorce
\(South \rightarrow Divorce = 10\) How much higher, on average, divorce is in the South than the North

title: DAGs II
section: Remove effect of South on divorce
text:
Remove effect of South on divorce
Regression subtracts out the effect of the South on divorce

title: DAGs II
section: Next: effect of South on waffles
text:
Next: effect of South on waffles
\(South \rightarrow Waffles = 8\) How many more, on average, Waffle Houses there are in the South than the North

title: DAGs II
section: Subtract out the effect of south on waffles
text:
Subtract out the effect of south on waffles
Regression subtracts out the effect of the South on waffles

title: DAGs II
text:
What‚Äôs left over?
The true effect of waffles on divorce \(\approx\) 0

title: DAGs II
text:
The perplexing pipe
Remember, with a perplexing pipe, controlling for Z blocks the effect of X on Y:

title: DAGs II
text:
Simulation
Let‚Äôs make up some data to show this: every unit of foreign aid increases corruption by 8; every unit of corruption increases the number of protest by 4


fake_pipe = tibble(aid = rnorm(n = 200, mean = 10), 
                   corruption = rnorm(n = 200, mean = 10) + 8 * aid, 
                   protest = rnorm(n = 200, mean = 10) + 4 * corruption)



What is the true effect of aid on protest? Tricky since the effect runs through corruption


For every unit of aid, corruption increases by 8; and for every unit of corruption, protest increases by 4‚Ä¶


The effect of aid on protest is \(4 \times 8 = 32\)

title: DAGs II
text:
Bad controls
Remember, with a pipe controlling for Z (corruption) is a bad idea

Let‚Äôs fit two models, where one makes the mistake of controlling for corruption



right_model = lm(protest ~ aid, data = fake_pipe)
bad_control = lm(protest ~ aid + corruption, data = fake_pipe)

title: DAGs II
text:
Bad controls
Notice how the model that mistakenly controls for Z tells you that X basically has no effect on Y (wrong)

title: DAGs II
text:
The exploding collider
Remember, with an exploding collider, controlling for M creates strange correlations between X and Y:

title: DAGs II
text:
Simulation
Let‚Äôs make up some data to show this:

fake_collider = tibble(x = rnorm(n = 100, mean = 10), 
                   y = rnorm(n = 100, mean = 10),
                   m = rnorm(n = 100, mean = 10) + 8 * x + 4 * y)


X has an effect of 8 on M
Y has an effect of 4 on M
X has no effect on Y

title: DAGs II
text:
Bad controls
What‚Äôs the true effect of X on Y? it‚Äôs zero
Remember, with a collider controlling for M is a bad idea
Let‚Äôs fit two models, where one makes the mistake of controlling for M

right_model = lm(y ~ x, data = fake_collider)
collided_model = lm(y ~ x + m, data = fake_collider)

title: DAGs II
text:
Colliding as sample selection
Most of the time when we see a collider, it‚Äôs because we‚Äôre looking at a weird sample of the population we‚Äôre interested in

Examples: the non-relationship between height and scoring, among NBA players; the (alleged) negative correlation between how surprising and reliable findings are, among published research

title: DAGs II
text:
Hiring at Google
Imagine Google wants to hire the best of the best, and they have two criteria: interpersonal skills, and technical skills

Say Google can measure how socially and technically skilled someone is (0-100)

fake_google = tibble(social_skills = rnorm(n = 200, mean = 50, sd = 10), 
                     tech_skills = rnorm(n = 200, mean = 50, sd = 10))



The two are causally unrelated: one does not affect the other; improving someone‚Äôs social skills would not hurt their technical skills

title: DAGs II
text:
General population
No relationship between social and technical skills among all job candidates

title: DAGs II
text:
Collided!
If we only look at Google workers we see a trade-off between social and technical skills:

title: DAGs II
text:
Limitations
It‚Äôs cool that we can control for a confound, or avoid colliders/pipes and get back the truth

But there are big limitations we must keep in mind when evaluating research:

We need to know what to control for (confident in our DAG)




We need to have data on the controls (e.g., data on Z)




We need our data to measure the variable well (e.g., # of homicides a good proxy for crime?)

title: DAGs II
text:
Stuff that‚Äôs hard to measure
Ability is a likely fork for the effect of Education on Earnings; but how do you measure ability?

title: DAGs II
text:

title: Causality II
text:
Causal diagram


We need a causal model
The model is our idea of how the data came to be (the data-generating process)
The model tells us how to identify a causal effect (if it‚Äôs possible!)

title: Causality II
text:
Directed Acyclical Graphs (DAGs)
A popular modeling tool for thinking about causality is the DAG
Nodes (points) = variables; Edges (arrows) = direction of causality

title: Causality II
text:
DAGs
Nodes = variables; Arrows = direction of causality










Read: X1 has an effect on Y

title: Causality II
text:
DAGs


X1 has an effect on Y; X2 has an effect on X1; X2 affects Y only through X1
Missing arrows matter!

Example of x2 - x1 - y?

title: Causality II
text:
DAGs


X1 has an effect on Y; X2 has an effect on X1 and Y (via X1); X3 has an effect on X1 and Y

title: Causality II
text:
Example: ideology
Where does (liberal) ideology come from?

Variables in the literature: Income (I), Liberal (L), Age (A), Media (M), Parents (P)












What are our assumptions? What‚Äôs this DAG saying?

title: Causality II
text:
DAGs
DAGs encode everything we know about some process

We can see all of our assumptions and how they fit together


For example: the effect of Parents on how Liberal someone is happens directly and indirectly (through Media)


Missing arrows also matter: we are assuming that Age has no effect on Media diet

title: Causality II
section: üö® Our turn: let‚Äôs make our own DAG üö®
text:
üö® Our turn: let‚Äôs make our own DAG üö®
On daggity.net about why people choose to vote (or not)

title: Causality II
text:
Identification
Why do this?

Later: DAGs help us figure out how to estimate the effect of one variable on another


While at the same time being mindful of all the other variables that we need to adjust, or control for


For instance, we might want to estimate the effect of Media consumption (M) on how Liberal (L) someone is


This process is called ‚Äúidentification‚Äù \(\rightarrow\) to identify the effect of X on Y

title: Causality II
text: Waffles and Divorce

title: Causality II
text: Waffle House Index

title: Causality II
text:
Does Waffle House cause divorce?
Do cheap, delicious waffles put marriages at risk?


Speculate on underlying mechanism

title: Causality II
text:
Does Waffle House cause divorce?

Almost certainly not


No one thinks there is a plausible way in which Waffle House causes divorce


When we see a correlation of this kind we wonder about other variables that are actually driving the relationship


You‚Äôve likely thought about this before: a ‚Äúlurking‚Äù variable, ‚Äúother factors‚Äù, that ‚Äúmatter‚Äù


But what might that variable be? And how exactly does it lead us astray?

title: Causality II
text:
The lurking variable
It turns out that Waffle Houses originated in the South (Georgia), and most of them are still there

The South also happens to have some of the highest divorce rates in the country

title: Causality II
text:
The DAG
So the DAG might look something like this: South has an effect on Waffle Houses and Divorce, but Waffles do not cause Divorce

title: Causality II
text:
The problem


A DAG like this will produce a correlation between Waffles and Divorce, even when there is no causal relationship


This is called confounding: the South is confounding the relationship between Waffles and Divorce

title: Causality II
text:
How does this happen?
Let‚Äôs make up data to convince ourselves this is true

fifty states, about half of them are in the South



tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE))

# A tibble: 50 √ó 1
   south
   <dbl>
 1     0
 2     1
 3     0
 4     0
 5     1
 6     0
 7     0
 8     1
 9     1
10     0
# ‚Ñπ 40 more rows








Note


sample() is choosing at random between 0 and 1, 50 times, with replacement

title: Causality II
text:
Simulate the treatment
Step 2: make Waffle houses, let‚Äôs say about 20 per million residents, +/- 4

tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
       waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4))

# A tibble: 50 √ó 2
   south waffle
   <dbl>  <dbl>

10     1  17.2 
# ‚Ñπ 40 more rows

title: Causality II
section: Make Waffles more common in the South
text:
Make Waffles more common in the South
Step 3: The arrow from South to Waffles, let‚Äôs say Southern states have about 10 more Waffles, on average

tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
       waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10 * south)

# A tibble: 50 √ó 2
   south waffle
   <dbl>  <dbl>
 1     0   14.5
 2     1   27.9
 3     1   30.6
 4     1   34.9
 5     0   26.8
 6     1   35.6
 7     1   28.4
 8     0   21.0
 9     0   26.1
10     1   33.4
# ‚Ñπ 40 more rows

title: Causality II
text:
Simulate the outcome
Step 4: make a divorce rate, let‚Äôs say about 20 divorces per 1,000 adults

fake = tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
              waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10 * south,
              divorce = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 2))

title: Causality II
section: Make the South have more divorce
text:
Make the South have more divorce
Step 5: the arrow from South to divorce, let‚Äôs say southern states have about 8 more divorces per 1,000 residents

fake = tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
              waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10 * south,
              divorce = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 2) + 8 * south)

NOTICE! Waffles have no effect on divorce in our fake data

title: Causality II
text:
A totally confounded relationship
The South‚Äôs effect on Waffle House and on Divorce creates a confounded correlation between the two

title: Causality II
text:
A totally confounded relationship
The DAG on the left will produce an association like the one on the right























Even if Waffles and Divorce are causally unrelated

title: Causality II
text:

Change the confound, treatment and outcome variables in the code to ones of your choosing
Alter the parameters in rnorm() so the values make sense for your variables
Make a scatterplot with a trend line ‚Äì use labs() to help us make sense of the plot axes and tell us what the confound is with the title = argument in labs()
Post in the Slack, winner (creativity + accuracy) wins small extra credit

title: Causality II
text:
What‚Äôs going on here?


Think of causality as water flowing in the direction of the arrows
We want look at water flowing directly from a treatment to an outcome
But account for the fact that there is often indirect flow that contaminates our estimates


Source: the mighty Andrew Heiss

title: Causality II
text:
What‚Äôs going on here?
To identify the effect of Waffles on Divorce we need to account, or control for, the influence of the South
Otherwise we will be confounded

title: Causality II
text:
The formula

Make a DAG of what we think is going on with our treatment and outcome
Figure out where the indirect flows are (today)
Account for those in our analysis (later in class)

title: Causality II
section: What do we need to control?
text:
What do we need to control?


Nothing

title: Causality II
section: What do we need to control?
text:
What do we need to control?


Nothing! No indirect flow to X

title: Causality II
section: What do we need to control?
text:
What do we need to control?


Nothing! No indirect flow to X!

title: Causality II
section: What do we need to control to identify‚Ä¶
text:
What do we need to control to identify‚Ä¶
Media consumption (M) \(\rightarrow\) Liberal (L)

title: Causality II
text: The elemental confounds

title: Causality II
text:
The confounding fork üç¥
Y \(\leftarrow\) Z \(\rightarrow\) X
There is a third variable, Z, that is a common cause of X and Y

title: Causality II
text:
The confounding fork
We‚Äôve already seen this!











Creates an association between X and Y that isn‚Äôt causal










Distorts the true causal relation between X and Y


Note that both of these fork scenarios will confound

title: Causality II
text:
The second scenario
Say that Waffles do cause Divorce, but the effect is tiny

fake = tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
              waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10*south,
              divorce = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 2) + 8*south + .0001 * waffle)

Same code as before, I‚Äôve just added a tiny effect of waffle houses on divorce = .0001 more divorces per waffle house

title: Causality II
text:
The second scenario
The effect of Z (South) on X (Waffles) and Y (Divorce) will distort our estimates:

mod = lm(divorce ~ waffle, data = fake) 
tidy(mod)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 5
  term        estimate std.error statistic      p.value
  <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>        <dbl>
1 (Intercept)   10.1      2.07        4.89 0.0000118   
2 waffle         0.555    0.0857      6.48 0.0000000464



Estimate is \(\frac{estimated}{true}\) = 5553.256633 times larger than the true effect!

title: Causality II
text:
Dealing with forks
We need to figure out what Z is, measure it, and adjust for it in our analysis

title: Causality II
text:
The perplexing pipe üö∞
X \(\rightarrow\) Z \(\rightarrow\) Y
X causes Z, which causes Y (or: Z mediates the effect of X on Y)










What happens if we adjust for Z? We block the effect of X on Y

title: Causality II
text:
An example: foreign intervention
What effect does US foreign wars have on US support abroad?

Say the DAG looks like this:









If we control for casualties we are blocking the effect of intervention on support

title: Causality II
text:
An example: foreign intervention
What if the DAG instead looked like this:


What does it mean

title: Causality II
text:
An example: foreign intervention
Two ways that War affects US sentiment: directly and indirectly
Adjusting for casualties blocks the indirect effect; if that‚Äôs what we want, fine ‚Äì But if we want the full effect then we‚Äôll be wrong!


What does it mean

title: Causality II
section: Pipes: why are they even a problem?
text:
Pipes: why are they even a problem?
Just leave pipes alone! It‚Äôs a problem of ‚Äúover-adjusting‚Äù

Bad social science: sometimes we are so afraid of forks that we control for everything we have data on


Especially when a process seems very complicated

title: Causality II
text:
Example: where pipes go wrong
The effects of smoking on heart problems might be complex; lots of potential confounds to worry about

Researcher might think they need to control for a study subject‚Äôs cholesterol because cholesterol affects heart health


‚ÄúWe should compare people who smoke but have similar levels of cholesterol, because cholesterol affects heart health‚Äù

title: Causality II
text:
Example: where pipes go wrong
If the DAG looks like this, cholesterol is a pipe and controlling is bad!

title: Causality II
text:
The explosive collider üí•
\(X \rightarrow Z \leftarrow Y\)

X and Y have a common effect


Left alone, it‚Äôs no problem; but controlling for Z creates strange patterns

title: Causality II
text:
Example: the NBA


Should the NBA stop worrying about height when drafting players?

title: Causality II
text:
No!
Obviously, height helps in basketball

But among NBA players there might be no relationship between height and scoring, because‚Ä¶


The shorter players who are drafted have other advantages


Among NBA players = adjusting, or controlling for, being in the NBA

title: Causality II
text:
Another example: bad findings


Richard McElreath asks: why are surprising findings so often untrustworthy?

title: Causality II
text: Another example: bad findings

title: Causality II
text:
It‚Äôs a collider
Imagine that in reality there is no relationship between how surprising a finding is and how trustworthy it is

title: Causality II
text:
It‚Äôs a collider
But now imagine that studies are only published either if they‚Äôre very trustworthy OR very surprising

title: Causality II
text:
It‚Äôs a collider
By only looking at published papers (e.g., controlling for publication), we create a negative relationship that doesn‚Äôt exist

title: Causality II
text:
Exploding colliders
Like pipes, colliders are a problem of controlling for the wrong thing
They are often the result of a sample selection problem
They can obscure actual relationships or fabricate non-existent ones
We need to avoid controlling for colliders; but they are everywhere!

title: Causality II
text:
üí• Your turn: colliders üí•
How are the following examples of colliders?

Among employees at Google, there is a strong negative correlation between technical skills and social skills.
A study of people who tested for COVID finds that people who smoke regularly are less likely to develop COVID-19. A real study!


we are conditioning on testing, these are the only people we observe anything that‚Äôs correlated with likelihood of testing here becomes a problem who gets tested? imagine that healthcare workers get tested a lot, and that people who actually have COVID 19 are tested a lot so smokers with no symptoms are very unlikely to be in the data so of those tested, non-smokers are more likely to have COVID19 than smokers

title: Prediction
text:
Why predict?



Companies, policymakers, and academics want to predict
who will win an election
whether UN peacekeepers can reduce conflict
whether you‚Äôll get the vaccine or not
At stake is what decision to take under uncertainty about the future

title: Prediction
text:
Making predictions


The basics of prediction are pretty straightforward:

Take/collect existing data ‚úÖ
Fit a model to it ‚úÖ
Design a scenario you want a prediction for ‚òëÔ∏è
Use the model to generate an estimate for that scenario ‚òëÔ∏è

title: Prediction
text:
What‚Äôs the scenario?



A scenario is a hypothetical observation (real, or imagined) that we want a prediction for
You define a scenario by picking values for explanatory variables
Example: what is the predicted fuel efficiency for a car that weighs 3 tons?
Example: what vote share should we expect for Democrats in a county with a median income of 45k, a large urban center, and where the percent of non-white residents is 50%?

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (by hand)

weight_model = lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars)

Remeber our model is an equation:

\(\widehat{mpg} = 37.29 - 5.34(wt)\)


We only have one explanatory variable to work with (wt), so our scenario can only rely on weight


Scenario: a car that weights 3.25 tons \(\rightarrow\) what fuel efficiency should we expect?


To get an estimate of mpg, we simply plug in the value of ‚Äúweight‚Äù we are interested in:


Estimate for weight = 3.25
\(\widehat{mpg} = 37.29 - 5.34 \times \color{red}{3.25} = 19.935\)

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (in R)
First define the scenario we want a prediction for, using crossing()


weight_scenario = crossing(wt = 3.25) 
weight_scenario

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
     wt
  <dbl>
1  3.25




Note that I store this as a data object








Note


the variables in crossing have to have the same name as the variables in the model

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (in R)
We can then combine our scenario with our model using augment()

augment(weight_model, newdata = weight_scenario)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
     wt .fitted
  <dbl>   <dbl>
1  3.25    19.9



augment takes the values for our scenario and plugs them in to our model equation to get an estimate


Note we got the same answer as when we did it by hand






Note


We tell augment what our new scenario is using the newdata = argument

title: Prediction
text:
Multiple scenarios
We can also look at multiple scenarios, maybe a light, medium, and heavy car:


weight_scenario = crossing(wt = c(1.5, 3, 5)) 
weight_scenario

# A tibble: 3 √ó 1
     wt
  <dbl>
1   1.5
2   3  
3   5  




And then use augment to get the estimates:

augment(weight_model, newdata = weight_scenario)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
     wt .fitted
  <dbl>   <dbl>
1   1.5    29.3
2   3      21.3
3   5      10.6

title: Prediction
text:
Sequence of scenarios
Or we can look at a sequence of scenarios using the seq() function

Example: estimates for every weight between 2 and 6 tons, in .1 ton increments



seq_weights = crossing(wt = seq(from = 2, to = 6, by = .1)) 
seq_weights

# A tibble: 41 √ó 1
      wt
   <dbl>
 1   2  
 2   2.1
 3   2.2
 4   2.3
 5   2.4
 6   2.5
 7   2.6
 8   2.7
 9   2.8
10   2.9
# ‚Ñπ 31 more rows








Note


seq needs a starting point (from), an end point (to), and an interval (by)

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (in R)
And then get predictions for all these scenarios:

augment(weight_model, newdata = seq_weights)

# A tibble: 41 √ó 2
      wt .fitted
   <dbl>   <dbl>
 1   2      26.6
 2   2.1    26.1
 3   2.2    25.5
 4   2.3    25.0
 5   2.4    24.5
 6   2.5    23.9
 7   2.6    23.4
 8   2.7    22.9
 9   2.8    22.3
10   2.9    21.8
# ‚Ñπ 31 more rows

title: Prediction
text:
Trivial
Do we really need a model to predict MPG when weight = 3.25? Probably not

title: Prediction
text:
Multiple regression
The real power of modeling and prediction comes with using multiple explanatory variables

Many factors influence a car‚Äôs fuel efficiency; we can use that information to make more precise predictions

title: Prediction
text:
Multiple regression
Here, a car‚Äôs fuel efficiency is a function of its weight (wt), number of cylinders (cyl), horse power (hp), and whether its transmission is manual or automatic (am)

big_model = lm(mpg ~ wt + cyl + hp + am, data = mtcars)


The model equation we want in the end is this one:
\[\operatorname{mpg} = \beta_0 + \color{red}{\beta_{1}}(\operatorname{wt}) + \color{red}{\beta_{2}}(\operatorname{cyl}) + \color{red}{\beta_{3}}(\operatorname{hp}) + \color{red}{\beta_{4}}(\operatorname{am})\]

title: Prediction
text:
Multiple regression



Just as when we had one variable, our OLS model is trying to find the values of \(\beta\) that ‚Äúbest‚Äù fits the data
OLS estimator = \(\sum{(Y_i - \hat{Y_i})^2}\)
Where \(\widehat{Y} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + . . . \beta_4 x_4\)
Now searching for \(\beta_0 ... \beta_4\) to minimize loss function











lm() hard at work

title: Prediction
text:
Interpretation








term
estimate




(Intercept)
36.15


wt
-2.61


cyl
-0.75


hp
-0.02


am
1.48










wt = every ton of weight is associated with a 2.61 decrease in mpg
cyl = every cylinder is associated with a .7 decrease in mpg
hp = every unit of horse power is associated with a .02 decrease in mpg
am = on average, cars with manual transmissions (am = 1) have 1.48 more mpg than cars with automatic transmissions (am = 0)










Note


Note how the estimate on weight changed as we added more variables

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (by hand)
We can make predictions just as before, plugging in values for our explanatory variables
\[
\operatorname{\widehat{mpg}} = 36.15 - 2.61(\operatorname{wt}) - 0.75(\operatorname{cyl}) - 0.02(\operatorname{hp}) + 1.48(\operatorname{am})
\]

With more variables, we can create more specific scenarios


For example: a car that weighs 3 tons, has 4 cylinders, 120 horsepower, and has a manual transmission


\[
\operatorname{\widehat{mpg}} = 36.15 - 2.61 \times \color{blue}{3} - 0.75 \times  \color{blue}{4} - 0.02 \times  \color{blue}{120} + 1.48 \times  \color{blue}{1}
\]


\[
\operatorname{\widehat{mpg}} = 24
\]

title: Prediction
text:
Prediction (in R)
We can do this in R with crossing() and augment()


big_scenario = crossing(wt = 3, cyl = 4, hp = 120, am = 1)

augment(big_model, newdata = big_scenario)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
     wt   cyl    hp    am .fitted
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
1     3     4   120     1    23.8

title: Prediction
text:
Troubleshooting
Note that your scenario needs to include every variable in your model, otherwise you will get an error

The one below is missing cylinders, which is in big_model, and won‚Äôt run:



bad_scenario = crossing(wt = 3, 
                      hp = 120,
                      am = 1)

augment(big_model, newdata = bad_scenario)

title: Prediction
text:
Pick scenarios that make sense

Note that to make predictions that make sense, we have to look through our data and see what values are plausible for the variables


For example, a scenario where we set am = 3 doesn‚Äôt make sense, since am is a dummy variable that takes two values (0 = automatic, 1 = manual)


But R doesn‚Äôt know that, and will give you (nonsensical) estimates:

crazy_car = crossing(wt = 3, cyl = 4, hp = 120, am = 3)
augment(big_model, newdata = crazy_car)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
     wt   cyl    hp    am .fitted
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
1     3     4   120     3    26.8








Note


Remember data |> distinct(variable) to see a variable‚Äôs values

title: Prediction
text:
Holding all else constant
One cool part of multiple regression is that we can see what happens to our estimates when one variable changes but the others are held at a fixed value

Holding all else in the model constant, how does increasing a car‚Äôs horsepower change its fuel efficiency?


We can use seq() to see what happens when horsepower changes while everything else is left at a fixed value



varying_hp = crossing(wt = 3, cyl = 4, am = 1, hp = seq(from = 50, to = 340, by = 5))

augment(big_model, newdata = varying_hp)

# A tibble: 59 √ó 5
      wt   cyl    am    hp .fitted
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1     3     4     1    50    25.6
 2     3     4     1    55    25.5
 3     3     4     1    60    25.3
 4     3     4     1    65    25.2
 5     3     4     1    70    25.1
 6     3     4     1    75    25.0
 7     3     4     1    80    24.8
 8     3     4     1    85    24.7
 9     3     4     1    90    24.6
10     3     4     1    95    24.5
# ‚Ñπ 49 more rows

title: Prediction
text:
Visualizing predictions
We could then store our estimate, and use it for plotting

hp_pred = augment(big_model, newdata = varying_hp)
ggplot(hp_pred, aes(x = hp, y = .fitted)) + geom_point()

title: Prediction
text:
One more example: Gapminder
Say we wanted to predict a country‚Äôs life expectancy, using population, GDP per capita, the year, and what continent it is in:


life_model = lm(lifeExp ~ gdpPercap + pop + year + continent, data = gapminder)
tidy(life_model)

# A tibble: 8 √ó 5
  term              estimate std.error statistic   p.value

8 continentOceania   2.06e+1   1.47e+0     14.0  3.39e- 42

title: Prediction
text:
Predicting health
Scenario: what if we wanted to predict the life expectancy of a country with a GDP per capita of $7,000, a population of 20 million, in the year 2005, in Asia?


life_scenario = crossing(gdpPercap = 7000, 
                       pop = 20000000, year = 2005, 
                       continent = "Asia")
augment(life_model, newdata = life_scenario)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
  gdpPercap      pop  year continent .fitted
      <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr>       <dbl>
1      7000 20000000  2005 Asia         67.0

title: Prediction
text:
Imaginary changes
What if we could ‚Äúdial up‚Äù this country‚Äôs GDP slowly? How would its life expectancy change?

Scenario: we can vary GDP and keep all else constant



life_scenario = crossing(gdpPercap = seq(from = 5000, to = 100000, by = 5000), 
                       pop = 20000000, year = 2005,

title: Prediction
text:
Imaginary scenarios
How different would this all look in different continents? We can vary continents too:


life_continent_scenario = crossing(gdpPercap = seq(from = 5000, to = 100000, by = 5000), 
                       pop = 20000000, year = 2005, 
                       continent = c("Asia", "Africa", "Americas", "Europe")) 
augment(life_model, newdata = life_continent_scenario)

# A tibble: 80 √ó 5

Prediction accuracy



The question with prediction is always: how accurate were we?
If our model is predicting the outcome accurately that might be:

a good sign that we are modeling the process that generates the outcome well
useful for forcasting the future, or situations we don‚Äôt know about

title: Prediction
text:
Is this really a prediction?



Our estimate of Jamaica is not really prediction, since we used that observation to fit our model
This is an in-sample prediction \(\rightarrow\) seeing how well our model does at predicting the data that we used to generate it
‚ÄúTrue‚Äù prediction is out-of-sample \(\rightarrow\) using a model to generate predictions about something that hasn‚Äôt happened yet







Figure. Is catch and release really fishing?

title: Prediction
text:
Out of sample prediction
Imagine in the year 1957 we fit a model with the info we had available at the time:


gap_57 = gapminder %>% filter(year <= 1957)
mod_57 = lm(lifeExp ~ gdpPercap + pop + continent + year, data = gap_57)



Now it‚Äôs 2007, someone finds the model, and wants to know: how well could this model have predicted the future?



jamaica = crossing(continent = "Americas", year = 2007, pop = 2780132, gdpPercap = 7321)



This is an out-of-sample prediction: our model has data before 1957, but our prediction is based off of Jamaica‚Äôs characteristics in 2007

title: Modeling I
text:
Patterns in the data



So far: wrangling and visualizing data
Looking for patterns (hopefully real)
Examples?

title: Modeling I
text:
Patterns and correlations

A useful way to talk about these patterns is in terms of correlations

When we see a pattern between two (or more) variables, we say they are correlated; when we don‚Äôt see one, we say they are uncorrelated


Correlations can be strong or weak, positive or negative

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlations: strength
When two variables ‚Äúmove together‚Äù, the correlation is strong
When they don‚Äôt ‚Äúmove together‚Äù, the correlation is weak

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlations: strength
Better heuristic: knowing about one variable tells you something about the other



Strong: if you know how a county voted in 2012, you have a good guess for 2016
Weak: if you know a county‚Äôs average commute time, you know almost nothing about how it votes

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlation: strength
We also talk (informally) about correlations that include categorical variables
Big gaps between groups \(\rightarrow\) correlated

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlation: direction
‚ûï: When two variables move ‚Äúin the same direction‚Äù
‚ûñ: When two variables move ‚Äúin opposite directions‚Äù

title: Modeling I
text:
Quantifying correlation
When the two variables are continuous, we can quantify the correlation
\[r =
  \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y}) }{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]

Correlation coefficient, r:
ranges from -1 to 1,
perfectly correlated = 1 or -1,
perfectly uncorrelated = 0


All of the movement is here: \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})\)

title: Modeling I
text:
Quantifying correlation

Lots of big, positive products \(\rightarrow\) strong positive correlation


Lots of big, negative products \(\rightarrow\) strong negative correlation


A mix of positive and negative products \(\rightarrow\) weak correlation

Interpreting the coefficient

Correlation coefficient: just a number

title: Modeling I
text:
üö® Our turn: correlations üö®
What do these pair-wise correlations from elections tell us?

title: Modeling I
text:
Models



Models are everywhere in social science (and industry)
Beneath what ads you see, movie recs, election forecasts, social science research \(\rightarrow\) a model
In the social sciences, we use models to describe how an outcome changes in response to a treatment

title: Modeling I
text:
The moving parts



The things we want to study in the social sciences are complex
Why do people vote? We can think of lots of factors that go into this decision
Voted = Age + Interest in politics + Free time + Social networks + . . .
Models break up (decompose) the variance in an outcome into a set of explanatory variables

title: Modeling I
text:
Speaking the language






Y
X




Outcome variable
Treatment variable


Response variable
Explanatory variable


Dependent variable
Independent variable


What is being changed
What is causing the change in Y








Maybe you‚Äôve seen some of these terms before; here‚Äôs what we will use

title: Modeling I
text:
Model cars
Say we want to model how changing a car‚Äôs weight (treatment) affects its fuel efficiency (outcome)

title: Modeling I
text:
Modeling weight and fuel efficiency
Very strong, negative correlation (r = -.9)

title: Modeling I
text:
Why a model?

Graph + correlation just gives us direction and strength of relationship


What if we wanted to know what fuel efficiency to expect if a car weighs 3 tons, or 6.2?

title: Modeling I
text:
Lines as models

There‚Äôs many ways to model relationships between variables


A simple model is a line that ‚Äúfits‚Äù the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù


The line of best fit describes how fuel efficiency changes as weight changes

title: Modeling I
text:
Strength of relationship
The slope of the line quantifies the strength of the relationship

Slope: -5.3 \(\rightarrow\) for every ton of weight you add to a car, you lose 5 miles per gallon

title: Modeling I
text:
Guessing where there‚Äôs no data
Line also gives us ‚Äúbest guess‚Äù for the fuel efficiency of a car with a given weight

even where we have no data


best guess for 4.5 ton car \(\rightarrow\) 13 mpg

title: Modeling I
text:
Drawing lines in R
We can add a trend-line to a graph using geom_smooth(method = "lm")


ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Modeling I
section: Where does this line come from?
text:
Where does this line come from?
Remember that a straight line takes the following form



6th grade algebra notation:
\(Y = b + mx\)
Y = a number
x = a number
m = the slope \(\frac{rise}{run}\)
b = the intercept



Statistical notation:
\(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_{1} x\)
\(Y\) = a number
\(x1\) = a number
\(\beta_1\) = the slope \(\frac{rise}{run}\)
\(\beta_0\) = the intercept




If you know \(\beta_0\) (intercept) and \(\beta_1\) (slope) you can draw a line

title: Modeling I
text: Some lines

title: Modeling I
text:
Which line to draw?
We could draw many lines through this data; which is ‚Äúbest‚Äù?

title: Modeling I
text:
Drawing the line
We need to find the intercept (\(\beta_0\)) and slope (\(\beta_1\)) that will ‚Äúfit‚Äù the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù
\(mpg_{i} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight_{i}\)

title: Modeling I
section: What does it mean to ‚Äúfit well‚Äù?
text:
What does it mean to ‚Äúfit well‚Äù?



Models use a rule for defining what it means to fit the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù
This rule is called a loss function
Different models use different loss functions
We‚Äôll look at the most popular modeling approach:
ordinary least squares (OLS)

title: Modeling I
text:
The loss function for OLS

The loss function for OLS (roughly!) says:


a line fits the data well if the sum of all the squared distances between the line and each data point is as small as possible


\(Y_i\) is the data point \(\rightarrow\) value of observation \(i\) \(\rightarrow\) the mpg of car \(i\)


\(\widehat{Y_i}\) is the line \(\rightarrow\) the mpg our line predicts for a car with that weight \(\rightarrow\)


\(\beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight\)


Distance between each point and line = \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})\)

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(Y_i\) = actual MPG for the Toyota Corolla

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(\widehat{Y_i}\) = our model‚Äôs predicted MPG (\(\beta_0\) + \(\beta_1 \times weight\)) for the Corolla

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i}\) = the distance between the data point and the line

title: Modeling I
text:
Back to the loss function
\(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i}\) is the distance between the point and the line

OLS uses the squared distances: \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2\)


The sum of the squared distances: \(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2}\)


Remember that \(\widehat{Y_i} = \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight\)


So can rewrite: \(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2} = \sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight)^2}\)


So we need to pick \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) to make this as small as possible (minimize):
\(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight)^2}\)

title: Modeling I
text:
Estimating the parameters

How do we find the specific \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that minimize the loss function?


Zooming out (not just OLS): in modeling there are two kinds of approaches





Statistical theory: make some assumptions and use math to find \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)



Computational: make some assumptions and use brute force smart guessing to find \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)





Sometimes (1) and (2) will produce the same answer; other times only (1) or (2) is possible

title: Modeling I
text:
Computational approach
Imagine an algorithm that:

Draws a line through the data by picking values of \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)
Sees how far each point is from the line
Sum up all the squared distances for that line (remember OLS calls for squaring!)
Rinse, repeat with a new line


The pair of \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that produce the line with the smallest sum of squared distances is our OLS estimator

title: Modeling I
text:
Strawman comparison
Which line fits the data better? (Duh)

title: Modeling I
text:
First candidate: fit the line
Rough guess: what is \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) here?

title: Modeling I
text:
First candidate: the residuals
How far is each point from the line? This is \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})\)

Also known as the residual \(\approx\) how wrong the line is about each point

title: Modeling I
text:
How good is line 1?
Remember, our loss function says that a good line has small \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2\)

title: Modeling I
text:
The best line

This is what geom_smooth() is doing under-the-hood (sorry)


It‚Äôs using math to figure out which line fits the data best


Conceptual best = the line that is closest to all the points


Math best = the smallest sum of squared residuals

title: Modeling I
section: So who are the winning Betas?
text:
So who are the winning Betas?


\(Y = \beta_0 + \beta1x_1\)
\(mpg = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight\)
\(mpg = 37 + -5 \times weight\)

text:
Data, objects, variables

trade_2010 and trade are both objects, year is a variable

trade_2010 = trade |> 
  filter(year == 2010)

title: Relationships I
text:
Data, objects, variables
Confusing! imports_gdp is an object that contains a variable that‚Äôs also named imports_gdp

imports_gdp = 
  trade |> 
  mutate(imports_gdp = imports / gdp)



This is why we need to pick good variable names!

title: Relationships I
text:
A common mistake
Say we wanted to multiply GDP per capita by population and plot the result:

gap_gdp = gapminder |> 
  mutate(gdp = gdpPercap * pop)


‚ùå

ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = year, y = gap_gdp)) + geom_point()

Mistake: using the original gapminder data, treating gap_gdp as a variable


‚úÖ

ggplot(gap_gdp, aes(x = year, y = gdp)) + geom_point()

Correct: use the new data object, which contains the newly created variable gdp

title: Relationships I
text:
Summarizing data

Often, with data, we want to compare things


Are democracies more peaceful than autocracies?


Does early-voting increase turnout?


To do this, we often rely on statistical summaries of our data:


Means, medians, minimums, maximums, variances

title: Relationships I
text:
Summary stats

The mean: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) \(\frac{(3 + 4 + 8)}{3} = 5\)


The median: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 4


The minimum: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 3


The maximum: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 8

title: Relationships I
text:
Example: an experiment
Some counties let people vote early; others don‚Äôt

Do counties with early provisions have higher turnout?

Quantifying ‚Äúhigher‚Äù
We can compare the averages of counties that do have early voting against those that don‚Äôt:

title: Relationships I
text:
Mean vs.¬†median
We almost always compare averages, but medians are helpful in some cases:











What‚Äôs happening here?

title: Relationships I
text:
One more stat: variation

Another way to compare data is by how much a variable varies


Some distributions are very narrow, others are very wide


Narrow = observations are similar; wide = observations are not similar

title: Relationships I
text:
Measuring variation: the standard deviation
The formula:
\[ s = \sqrt{\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{i=1}^N (x_i - \overline{x})^2}\]

All the movement is here, the sum of the differences between each observation \(x_i\) and the average observation \(\overline{x}\)
\[\sum_{i=1}^N (x_i - \overline{x})^2\]

title: Relationships I
text:
Measuring variation
Same average (~$50,000), different standard deviations


What could we measure with sd? Can we use standard deviation to measure equality?

title: Relationships I
text:
Summary statistics with summarize()
We can use summarize() to calculate things like the mean, median, etc.


Summarizing condenses data into statistics

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()
Say I want to know the average life expectancy in the world in 2007:


gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007)

# A tibble: 142 √ó 6
   country     continent  year lifeExp       pop gdpPercap
   <fct>       <fct>     <int>   <dbl>     <int>     <dbl>
 1 Afghanistan Asia       2007    43.8  31889923      975.
 2 Albania     Europe     2007    76.4   3600523     5937.

 4 Angola      Africa     2007    42.7  12420476     4797.
 5 Argentina   Americas   2007    75.3  40301927    12779.
 6 Australia   Oceania    2007    81.2  20434176    34435.

10 Belgium     Europe     2007    79.4  10392226    33693.
# ‚Ñπ 132 more rows

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()

gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize()

# A tibble: 1 √ó 0

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()

gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_life
     <dbl>
1     67.0


Notice how the data has been summarized: only one row

Notice that I‚Äôve named the summary statistic avg_life

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the median life expectancy?


gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), 
            med_life = median(lifeExp)) 

# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
  avg_life med_life
     <dbl>    <dbl>
1     67.0     71.9


Notice! how similar this looks to mutate()

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the min and max life expectancy?


gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), 
            med_life = median(lifeExp), 
            min_life = min(lifeExp), 
            max_life = max(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 4
  avg_life med_life min_life max_life
     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1     67.0     71.9     39.6     82.6

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the standard deviation of life expectancy?


gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), 
            med_life = median(lifeExp), 
            min_life = min(lifeExp), 
            max_life = max(lifeExp), 
            sd_life = sd(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
  avg_life med_life min_life max_life sd_life
     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl>
1     67.0     71.9     39.6     82.6    12.1

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()

gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
  summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), 
            med_life = median(lifeExp), 
            min_life = min(lifeExp), 
            max_life = max(lifeExp), 
            sd_life = sd(lifeExp)) 


summarize() is like mutate() in that you are creating new variables


So note that you have to name the new variables!

Woe unto us: missing data

In life, sometimes data is missing


respondent doesn‚Äôt answer a question, no one knows Afghanistan‚Äôs GDP in 1943, etc.


R represents missing data as NA

title: Relationships I
text:
Summarizing with missing data
If you try to summarize data that has missing values, R will return NA:


pokemon %>% 
  summarise(average_height = mean(height_m))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1             NA










Note


Any math operation with NA will return NA (.e.g, 3 + NA = NA)

title: Relationships I
text:
What to do?

There are whole classes on what to do with missing data (impute, simulate, model, etc.)


In this class we will tell R to ignore missing observations


We can do this by adding the na.rm = TRUE argument to summary

pokemon %>% 
  summarise(average_height = mean(height_m, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1           1.16

title: Relationships I
text:
Remember‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre trying to calculate a summary statistic and keep getting NA‚Ä¶


99.99999% of the time you need to add na.rm = TRUE to your function!



pokemon %>% 
  summarise(average_height = mean(height_m, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1           1.16

Relationships

summarize() lets us calculate statistics for the whole dataset


But what if we want to do this for different groups within the data?


This is at the heart of making comparisons

title: Data wrangling I
text:
What is data-wrangling?


‚Ä¶the process of transforming and mapping data from one ‚Äúraw‚Äù data form into another format with the intent of making it more appropriate and valuable for a variety of downstream purposes such as analytics‚Ä¶ Data analysts typically spend the majority of their time in the process of data wrangling compared to the actual analysis of the data. ‚Äì Wikipedia



Most of your time working with data will be spent wrangling it into a usable form for analysis

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Pipes: connecting data to functions

directors_profit = movies |> 
  # only look at horror movies
  filter(genre1 == "Horror" | genre2 == "Horror" | genre3 == "Horror") |> 
  # calculate profit
  mutate(profit = gross - budget)


You‚Äôve seen these before‚Ä¶

title: Data wrangling I
text:
What are pipes?



Pipes link data to functions
They look like this %>%, or |>
Definitely use keyboard shortcuts

OSX: Cmd + Shift + M
Windows: Ctrl + Shift + M

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Why pipes?

With pipes: üòç

penguins %>% 
  filter(species == "Adelie") %>% 
  mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000) %>% 
  select(body_mass_kg)



Without pipes: ü§¢

select(mutate(filter(penguins, species == "Adelie"), body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000), body_mass_kg)




Both produce the same output, but pipes make code more legible

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Making sense of pipes: ‚Äúand then‚Ä¶‚Äù

directors_profit = movies %>% 
  # only look at horror movies
  filter(genre1 == "Horror" | genre2 == "Horror" | genre3 == "Horror") %>% 
  # calculate profit
  mutate(profit = gross - budget)



You can read the pipe as if it said ‚Äúand then‚Äù‚Ä¶



Take the data object movies, AND THEN
filter so genre1, genre2, or genre3 equal HORROR, AND THEN
mutate so that‚Ä¶

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Our first wrangling function: filter()

filter() subsets data objects based on rules












baby_subset <- babynames %>%
  filter(name == "Angel")

Subset babynames to only babies named Angel

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Why filter?

Lots of real-world applications: finding flights, addresses, IDs, etc.


Sometimes we want to focus on a specific subset of data: the South, Latin America, etc.


Useful to deal with common problems: outliers, missing data, strange responses

text:
The Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC)


Third largest welfare program in the US
Only people who meet certain criteria receive it
Effects of program and its design are hotly debated





What does this graph tell us about the criteria?

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Using filter()
To use filter(), we need to tell R which observations we want to include (or exclude) using rules



gap_africa = gapminder |> 
  filter(region == "Africa")

Rule: return all observations from gapminder where the region variable is equal to ‚ÄúAfrica‚Äù

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Making the rules: logical operators



Rules filter data based on whether variables meet certain criteria
Rules rely on logical operators:

Equal to, not equal to, less than, more than, included in, etc.
Observations that meet the rule are returned; those that are not are dropped

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The logical operators






Operator
meaning




==
equal to


!=
not equal to


>
greater than


<
less than


>=
greater than or equal to


<=
less than or equal to


&
AND (both conditions true)


|
OR (either condition is true)


%in%
IN (in the set of)









Why double equal sign?

Using filter()

text:
Apples

apples

# A tibble: 4 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Gala         green      4 TRUE 
3 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
4 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE








Note


The output reports how many rows and columns our dataset has (4 rows x 4 columns)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Green apples

apples |> 
  filter(color == "green")

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name      color pounds sweet
  <chr>     <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Gala      green      4 TRUE 
2 Macintosh green      8 FALSE



Notice words are in quotations!


Notice that the number of rows has decreased: 2 x 4

title: Data wrangling I
Data wrangling I
text:
Apples that aren‚Äôt green

apples |> 
  filter(color != "green")

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE


The ! symbol negates: not equal to

title: Data wrangling I
section: At least 4 pounds but less than 6

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Combinations: The OR (|) operator
‚ÄúObservations where either this is true OR that is true‚Äù

Apples that are red OR green

apples |> 
  filter(color == "red" | color == "green")

# A tibble: 4 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Gala         green      4 TRUE 
3 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
4 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE








Note


The | should be above your Return/Enter key

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Combinations: the AND operator (&)
The & operator can be used to combine rules

Returns observations where both rules are true


‚ÄúApples that are red AND sweet or green AND sour‚Äù:



apples |> 
  filter(color == "red" & sweet == TRUE | color == "green" & sweet == FALSE)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
%in%
The %in% operator is super powerful

It returns observations that belong to a set


Say I wanted to look at just South American countries, normally:

gapminder |> 
  filter(country == "Argentina" | country == "Brazil" | country == "Chile")

Brutally repetitive

title: Data wrangling I
text:
%in%
Make a list of countries and return observations that match any of them

keep = c("Argentina", "Brazil", "Chile")

gapminder |> filter(country %in% keep)







Note


To make a ‚Äúlist‚Äù of items (a vector), use c()

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The last step: creating objects
Step 1-2: the data, the pipe, the wrangling functions

apples |> 
  filter(sweet == FALSE)



Step 3: store the subsetted data as a new object for later use

green_apples = apples |>
  filter(sweet == FALSE)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Objects
In programming, objects can be used to store all sorts of stuff for later use

data, functions, values


We create objects using = or <-


Like this:

new_object = stuff |> filter(year == 1999)



Or like this:

new_object <- stuff |> filter(year == 1999)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Naming objects

There are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things. ‚Äì Phil Karlton


Recommend: keep it short, easy to type, informative, and use _ to separate words



# Good
gap_africa = gapminder |> 
  filter(continent == "Africa")

# Bad
Countries_In_Africa_That_I_Want_To_Look_Up = gapminder |> 
  filter(continent == "Africa")



I use the excellent Tidyverse syntax guide in my work

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Failure to object
Without objects, your work washes away, like tears in the rain



Here, we store our data wrangling


green_apples = apples |>
  filter(sweet == FALSE)

green_apples

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
2 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE




Here we didn‚Äôt store


apples |>
  filter(sweet == FALSE)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The formula
Wrangle the data until you‚Äôre satisfied with the output:

  filter(sweet == FALSE)


Store the output as a new object:

sour_apples = apples |> 
  filter(sweet == FALSE)



Use the new object (e.g., plotting):

ggplot(sour_apples, aes(x = name, y = pounds)) + geom_col()

title: Data visualization I
text:
The grammar of graphics

Graphs have an internal logic, or grammar that connects data to visuals


Data = variables in a dataset


Aesthetic = visual property of a graph (position, shape, color, etc.)


Geometry = representation of an aesthetic (point, line, text, etc.)

title: Importing data into R
text:
Most of the data in this course will come from packages. I do this so we have more time to focus on the stuff that matters. But most of the data in the world is not in a package. How can I read this kind of data into R?
There‚Äôs ways to do this in Rstudio through drop-down menus but I call that the ‚Äúno learning‚Äù approach.
To read data into R you need to know two things:

What kind of file is it? What is its extension?
Where is it? What is its file path?

title: Importing data into R
text:
Most of the data in this course will come from packages. I do this so we have more time to focus on the stuff that matters. But most of the data in the world is not in a package. How can I read this kind of data into R?
There‚Äôs ways to do this in Rstudio through drop-down menus but I call that the ‚Äúno learning‚Äù approach.
To read data into R you need to know two things:

What kind of file is it? What is its extension?
Where is it? What is its file path?

title: Importing data into R
section: What kind of file is it?
text:
What kind of file is it?
There are many different types of files out there. You can tell what type of file a dataset is by looking at its extension - the bit in the file name that comes after the period. Some common file types/extensions are .csv, .dta, .xlsx, etc.
R has different functions you can use to import different types of files. For a .csv file you would use read_csv() or read.csv(). For a .dta you would use read_dta() from the {haven} package. For an .xlsx file you would use read_excel() from {readxl}. If you‚Äôre not sure, google what function to use for a particular data file.

title: Importing data into R
text:
Where is it?
This part is tricky for people who don‚Äôt have a lot of experience working with computers. But, in short: every file that is on your computer has a ‚Äúpath‚Äù or ‚Äúaddress‚Äù that uniquely identifies it on your computer. This address changes with your file‚Äôs location; if you moved the file for whatever reason, the file path would change. You need the file path in order to tell R where to look at your data.
How to find it? Operating systems are always changing so in general the best thign is to google how to find a file‚Äôs filepath and then remember it. But the following seems to have worked on Mac for a long time now:

find the file in your Finder
right-click and select ‚Äúget info‚Äù
at the top left, under ‚ÄúGeneral‚Äù, you‚Äôll see the file path next to ‚ÄúWhere:‚Äù
right-click that path and select ‚Äúcopy as Pathname‚Äù

And on Windows you can do this.
Code to import data into R might look like this:

df = read_csv("/Users/juan/Dropbox/teaching/co2-data/owid-co2-data.csv")

title: Importing data into R
text:
How to do this better
For working on longer term projects, it is more convenient to use relative file paths in conjunction with something like R projects (.Rproj) + the {here} library.

title: Exam guides
text:
Note
This study guide is meant to help you; a student who knows all the below well should do well on the exam. It is not a contract. There is no room to negotiate over whether questions on the exams are perfectly represented in this list.

title: Exam guides
section: Things you should know for the midterm‚Ä¶
text:
Things you should know for the midterm‚Ä¶

The structure of data (what are rows, columns in a dataset)
The grammar of graphics (variables, aesthetics, geometries)
How to interpret patterns in data visualizations (e.g., general trends, outliers)
The different types of variables that exist (e.g., categorical, dummies)
The five graphs, what they tell us, and when each is appropriate
How to make these graphs in R
Use of pipes to connect functions
Why we would want to subset data and how to do it
Use of logical operators
Use of objects
Why we would want to create new variables and how to do it
How to make new categorical variables out of existing data
The summary statistics and what they tell us
How to calculate summary statistics, in general, and for subgroups in the data
How to summarize categorical variables
How we can ‚Äúbreak down‚Äù broad patterns in data to test theories or concerns about the relationships we‚Äôre observing
What correlations are, how we measure them, what they tell us
The basics of modeling, terminology, broad goals

title: Exam guides
section: Things you should know for the final‚Ä¶
text:
Things you should know for the final‚Ä¶

The intuition of how model parameters are estimated
How to fit models with different kinds of variables and interpret the output
How to interpret model output in multiple regression
Why we want to make predictions, and the mechanics of making them
How to assess whether our predictions are good or bad
The difference between prediction and causal inference
What ‚Äúcauses‚Äù means in social science terms
Why causal inference is difficult, the fundamental problem of causality
How to use simulation to create the varying causal patterns in data that we explored
Why experiments work and how they differ from observational inferences
Using, reading, and making DAGs
The different confounding scenarios we discussed
Use of controls, in theory and practice
The motivation for the causal revolution, natural experiments, why they work, how we know when we have one, limitations
Why we are uncertain, how to simulate uncertainty, how the law of large numbers saves us, when it can‚Äôt
How to quantify uncertainty and its use in hypothesis testing

title: Uncertainty
text:
Show sample estimates vary
Load the data:

# libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(stevedata)
library(moderndive)

# data
gss_abortion

# A tibble: 64,814 √ó 18
      id  year   age race  sex    hispaniccat  educ partyid       relactiv abany
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>            <dbl> <dbl>
 1     1  1972    23 White Female          NA    16 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 2     2  1972    70 White Male            NA    10 Not Str Demo‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 3     3  1972    48 White Female          NA    12 Independent         NA    NA
 4     4  1972    27 White Female          NA    17 Not Str Demo‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 5     5  1972    61 White Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 6     6  1972    26 White Male            NA    14 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 7     7  1972    28 White Male            NA    13 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 8     8  1972    27 White Male            NA    16 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 9     9  1972    21 Black Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
10    10  1972    30 Black Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
# ‚Ñπ 64,804 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 8 more variables: abdefect <dbl>, abnomore <dbl>, abhlth <dbl>,
#   abpoor <dbl>, abrape <dbl>, absingle <dbl>, pid <dbl>, hispanic <dbl>


What‚Äôs the true population parameter? Pretending dataset is full population:

## abortion true
gss_abortion |> 
  summarise(avg_abnomore = mean(abnomore, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_abnomore
         <dbl>
1        0.446


Show estimates vary across samples:

# take many little samples from population
samples = gss_abortion |> 
  rep_sample_n(size = 10, reps = 1000) |> 
  summarise(avg_abnomore = mean(abnomore, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(samples, aes(x = avg_abnomore)) + 
  geom_histogram()

title: Uncertainty
Uncertainty
text:
Bootstrapping
Look at the data:

## death penalty
issues = read_csv("https://www.dropbox.com/s/x5xncajqsz0q09l/voter-files-issues.csv?dl=1")

Average support for death penalty in Kansas:

just_kansas = issues |> 
  filter(state == "Kansas")
  
just_kansas |> summarise(avg_death = mean(deathpen_2016, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_death
      <dbl>
1     0.571


Bootstrap estimates:

boot_kansas = just_kansas |> 
  rep_sample_n(size = nrow(just_kansas), replace = TRUE,
               reps = 1000) |> 
  summarise(avg_death = mean(deathpen_2016, na.rm = TRUE))

Plot the estimates:

ggplot(boot_kansas, aes(x = avg_death)) + 
  geom_histogram()








Calculate the standard error:

# standard error
boot_kansas |> 
  summarise(standard_error = sd(avg_death))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  standard_error
           <dbl>
1         0.0702


Calculate the 95% CI:

# 95% CI
boot_kansas |> 
  summarise(low = quantile(avg_death, probs = .025),
            high = quantile(avg_death, probs = .975))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
    low  high
  <dbl> <dbl>
1 0.437 0.714

 07-causality.R

title: Causality
text:
class: make up a relationship
We use rnorm to simulate data. Three arguments: number of draws, mean, standard deviation:

rnorm(n = 5, mean = 10, sd = 2)

[1] 12.597806  9.037005  8.582153 10.629605  9.079209


We made up this data:

fake_election = tibble(party_share = rnorm(n = 500, mean = 50, sd = 5), 
                       funding = rnorm(n = 500, mean = 20000, sd = 4000) + 2000 * party_share)
fake_election

# A tibble: 500 √ó 2
   party_share funding
         <dbl>   <dbl>
 1        53.0 123590.
 2        57.0 136940.
 3        52.3 123661.
 4        43.4 104649.
 5        46.2 117465.
 6        46.1 115563.
 7        46.7 117569.
 8        41.2 106682.
 9        48.9 113562.
10        52.4 125225.
# ‚Ñπ 490 more rows


We can plot it:

ggplot(fake_election, aes(x = party_share, y = funding)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm")








Notice we made the causal effect equal 2000 dollars per percent of the vote won. We can estimate this and get pretty close using OLS:

mod = lm(funding ~ party_share, data = fake_election)
tidy(mod)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 5
  term        estimate std.error statistic   p.value
  <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
1 (Intercept)   19344.    1815.       10.7 5.05e- 24
2 party_share    2016.      36.1      55.8 1.73e-216


It‚Äôs close but not perfect because there is ‚Äúnoise‚Äù in our data. These numbers are randomly generated!

title: Causality
text:
class: confounds
Here we want to make it so a third variable, ‚Äúthe south‚Äù, confounds the relationship between the number of waffle houses in a state and the divorce rate:

fake = tibble(south = sample(c(0, 1), size = 50, replace = TRUE), 
              waffle = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 4) + 10 * south,
              divorce = rnorm(n = 50, mean = 20, sd = 2) + 8 * south)
fake

# A tibble: 50 √ó 3
   south waffle divorce
   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>
 1     0   27.3    18.1
 2     1   27.2    27.6
 3     1   32.8    30.9
 4     0   19.3    16.5
 5     1   25.3    28.6
 6     0   18.6    21.2
 7     0   17.2    17.3
 8     0   21.1    21.0
 9     1   31.7    28.1
10     0   15.0    20.9
# ‚Ñπ 40 more rows


We can plot:

ggplot(fake, (aes(x = waffle, y = divorce))) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm")








We can model to retrieve the confounded estimate:

lm(divorce ~ waffle, data = fake) |> broom::tidy()

text:
Here‚Äôs the code we‚Äôll be using in class:

Day one: üë©‚Äçüíª 04-wrangle-code.R
