title: Natural experiments
text:
Baby problems

Insurance will cover two nights in a hospital after delivery
But how long is ‚Äúa night‚Äù?
Nights counted by number of midnights (arbitrary cutoff)
üë∂ born on Monday at 11:59pm = gets Tue + Wed in hospital
üë∂ born on Tuesday at 12:01am = gets Tue + Wed + Thur in hospital (by chance, get extra minimum coverage)

title: Natural experiments
text:
Finding
1 in 4 babies born after midnight spend an extra night in hospital (üíµüíµüíµ), even when there is no health benefit to doing so

title: Natural experiments
section: Other examples: McNamara and the Whiz Kids
text:
Other examples: McNamara and the Whiz Kids



What effect did bombing raids in Vietnam have long-term?
Problem: the places that were bombed are very different from the places that were never bombed
Biggest confound: if bombing accurate, places that were most bombed had most Vietcong presence

title: Natural experiments
text:
McNamara and the Whiz Kids



Decision to bomb based on threat scoring system (1, very secure, to 5, very insecure)
Final score based on average of sub-scores, then rounded to whole number so:
4.4999 ‚Äì> 4, whereas 5.0001 -> 5 (arbitrary cutoff)
Paper shows long-term deleterious effects to bombing

title: Natural experiments
section: How do we know we have a natural experiment?
text:
How do we know we have a natural experiment?



In a true experiment, the treatment and control group should look similar or balanced demographically
i.e., if I put people into two groups at random, it should be very unlikely that the average person in the control is 22 years old and the average in treatment group is 55 years old
One thing we can do is compare the characteristics of the treatment and control group in our natural experiment; are they in fact similar?

title: Natural experiments
section: Are they similar? Back to the gifted program
text:
Are they similar? Back to the gifted program
It looks like people close to the cutoff are pretty balanced






Gifted?

Some evidence we have a natural experiment

title: Natural experiments
text:
Why some evidence?



If checking for balance is a way to see if we have a natural experiment, why can‚Äôt we always do this?
Want to know the effect of X on Y; test for balance on X; if balanced we are good to go / not confounded
Remember the problem is often we don‚Äôt know what confounds are out there! Or we know, but can‚Äôt measure them!
Checking for balance is suggestive, weak evidence that we have a natural experiment

title: Natural experiments
text:
Big picture
Natural experiments are ‚Äústrongest‚Äù causal tool, and regression discontinuity designs are probably the most convincing version

Easy to implement; less worry about confounding; the tough part? Finding one! And collecting the data


Often the result of some rule, boundary, or some other random, arbitrary process having a sudden impact in the world


Premium on: specific knowledge of a particular region/area/issue

title: Natural experiments
text:
üö® Your turn: üß†üß†üß† üö®
With the person to your right (or whatever):

Write down as many rules, demarcations, cutoffs, etc., out there in the world that you can think of.
Can any of these create an opportunity for a natural experiment, where something happens to some people/countries/places but not to others as a result of this rule/cutoff/thing?
What problem could that natural experiment help solve? In the gifted program case: the IQ test cutoff helps solve the problem of estimating the effect of gifted programs on future success.
Post a summary in the Slack and if the idea is good enough I will steal it and publish it.

title: Natural experiments
text:
No free lunch



Natural experiments are great but there are limitations:
Changing estimate If we find a good one, the thing we are trying to estimate likely changes (is this bad? depends)
Sorting at the cutoff If there‚Äôs a rule out there that has consequences, people will do what they can to end up on the right side of it

title: Natural experiments
text:
Limitations: changing estimates


By focusing on units near cutoff, our estimate subtly changes:

effect of putting a child in gifted on future earnings, on average
effect of putting a child with roughly 75 IQ in gifted on earnings ‚úÖ
Is this a problem? Depends, but better to know one narrow(er) fact that nothing at all?

title: Natural experiments
text:
Limitations: ‚Äúsorting around the cutoff‚Äù
There is also a risk that if people know about the cutoff they will behave strategically in ways that confound our estimate

Imagine that there is room to pressure/bully the school psychologist into turning a 74.9 into a 75 so little Timmy can be gifted


And image wealthier/better-connected/etc parents are better bullies than poor parents


In that case, being gifted is no longer random


wealthy parents cause you to get over the cutoff

title: Natural experiments
text:
Sorting around the cut-off
If parents can force almost-there kids into gifted, parents become a backdoor path to earnings (since your parents likely affect your earnings directly, or in other ways)

title: Natural experiments
section: üö® Your turn: sorting around the cutoff üö®

Could someone ‚Äúgame‚Äù or sort around that cutoff?

And how could it confound your estimate / ruin the natural experiment?

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The problem
We know our analysis is based on samples, and different samples give different answers:

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The way out



Turns out that if our samples are representative of the population, then estimates from large samples will tend to be pretty damn close
So if sample is good ‚úÖ and ‚Äúbig‚Äù ‚úÖ then most of the time we‚Äôll be OK ‚úÖ

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Two approaches


‚ùå Statistical theory

Make assumptions about distribution of samples from population
Design test based on those assumptions (t-test, z-test, etc.)


‚úÖ Simulation

Simulate different samples that look like ours
Use distribution of simulated samples to quantify uncertainty




In some cases, both get you to the same answer, in others, only one works

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Simulation
We want a sense for how uncertain we should feel on estimates drawn from our sample

Our sample is gss_sm, and we have 2,867 observations

title: Uncertainty II
text:
How to simulate
If we take lots of samples of size 20 \(\rightarrow\) uncertainty in a sample of 20

gss_sm %>%
  rep_sample_n(size = 20, reps = 1000)

title: Uncertainty II
text:
How to simulate
If we take lots of samples of size 100 \(\rightarrow\) uncertainty in a sample of 100

gss_sm %>%
  rep_sample_n(size = 100, reps = 1000)

title: Uncertainty II
text:
How to simulate
So to see how uncertain we should feel about gss_sm, we should take many samples that are the same size as gss_sm


gss_sm %>% 
  rep_sample_n(size = 2867, reps = 1000)









Note


nrow(DATA) tells you how many observations in data object

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Problem
If we have a dataset of 2,867 observations and ask R to randomly pick 2,867 observations, we‚Äôll just get a bunch of copies of the original dataset

gss_sm %>% 
  rep_sample_n(size = nrow(gss_sm), reps = 1000)


Solution: sample with replacement \(\rightarrow\) once we draw an observation it goes back into the dataset, ad can be sampled again



gss_sm %>% 
  rep_sample_n(size = nrow(gss_sm), reps = 1000, replace = TRUE)

title: Uncertainty II
text: Sampling with replacement

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Sampling with and without replacement
If we were sampling 4 of these delicious fruits:

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Bootstrapping



Generating many, same-sized samples with replacement is called bootstrapping
Replacement lets us generate samples that randomly differ from ours
Use the distribution of bootstrapped samples to quantify uncertainty







Only one sample? Pull yourself up by your bootstraps!

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The distribution of bootstrapped estimates
Our estimate and how much simulated estimates might vary across bootstrapped samples that look like ours

The red is the distribution of bootstrapped sample estimates \(\rightarrow\) the sampling distribution

title: Uncertainty II
text:
How to quantify uncertainty?


The red histogram is nice, but how can we communicate uncertainty in our estimates in a pithy, more comparable way?
Three approaches:

The standard error
The confidence interval
Statistical significance

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The standard error
One way to quantify uncertainty would be to measure how ‚Äúwide‚Äù the distribution of bootstrapped sample estimates is

As we learned so long ago, one way to measure the ‚Äúspread‚Äù of a distribution (i.e., how much a variable varies), is with the standard deviation


The standard deviation of the sampling distribution is called the standard error, or the margin of error





boot_kids %>% 
  summarise(mean = mean(avg_kids), 
            standard_error = sd(avg_kids))





mean
standard_error


1.85
0.0319









Best guess on how many kids the average American has? About 1.85 kids, +/- 2 standard errors

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Standard error
This is what you see in the news ‚Äì that +/- polling/margin of error

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Varying uncertainty
As our sample size increases, the standard error decreases

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The confidence interval
Another way to quantify uncertainty is to look where most estimates fall
this is the confidence interval: our ‚Äúbest guess‚Äù of what we‚Äôre trying to estimate

title: Uncertainty II
section: How big to make the interval?
text:
How big to make the interval?
You could report (for example) where the middle 50% of bootstraps fall, or (for example) where the middle 95% of bootstraps fall, but there are tradeoffs!

title: Uncertainty II
text:
The tradeoff

You are 50% ‚Äúconfident‚Äù that avg. number of kids could vary between 1.83 and 1.87. Narrower range! But low confidence!
You are 95% ‚Äúconfident‚Äù that avg. number of kids could vary between 1.79 and 1.92. Higher range! But higher confidence!

title: Uncertainty II
section: How big to make the interval?
text:
How big to make the interval?
Convention is to look at the middle 95% of the distribution

Where do the middle 95% of the bootstrap estimates fall?


We can use the quantile() function to get here

boot_kids %>% 
  summarise(low = quantile(avg_kids, .025), # middle 95% means lower bound is .025
            mean = mean(avg_kids), 
            high = quantile(avg_kids, .975)) # middle 95% means upper bound is .975





low
mean
high


1.79
1.85
1.92










The 95% confidence confidence interval for the average number of kids in the US is: (1.80, 1.91)

draw on board with middle 50% of distribution

title: Uncertainty II
text:
Mirrors of one another
The standard error and confidence interval are actually telling you the same thing

A 95% confidence interval is roughly equal to the Estimate +/- 1.96 \(\times\) standard error



boot_kids %>% 
  summarise(low = quantile(avg_kids, .025),
            mean = mean(avg_kids), 
            high = quantile(avg_kids, .975))





low
mean
high


1.79
1.85
1.92










boot_kids %>% 
  summarise(mean = mean(avg_kids), standard_error = sd(avg_kids)) %>% 
  mutate(low = mean - 1.96 * standard_error, 
         high = mean + 1.96 * standard_error) %>% 
  select(low, mean, high)





low
mean
high


1.79
1.85
1.91

title: Data visualization
text:
We‚Äôre working with elections_historic from the {socviz} package. This code loads {socviz}, {tidyverse} (where ggplot() lives) and the dataset:

library(tidyverse)
library(socviz)
elections_historic

# A tibble: 49 √ó 19
   election  year winner      win_party ec_pct popular_pct popular_margin  votes
      <int> <int> <chr>       <chr>      <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>  <int>
 1       10  1824 John Quinc‚Ä¶ D.-R.      0.322       0.309        -0.104  1.13e5
 2       11  1828 Andrew Jac‚Ä¶ Dem.       0.682       0.559         0.122  6.43e5
 3       12  1832 Andrew Jac‚Ä¶ Dem.       0.766       0.547         0.178  7.03e5
 4       13  1836 Martin Van‚Ä¶ Dem.       0.578       0.508         0.142  7.63e5
 5       14  1840 William He‚Ä¶ Whig       0.796       0.529         0.0605 1.28e6
 6       15  1844 James Polk  Dem.       0.618       0.495         0.0145 1.34e6
 7       16  1848 Zachary Ta‚Ä¶ Whig       0.562       0.473         0.0479 1.36e6
 8       17  1852 Franklin P‚Ä¶ Dem.       0.858       0.508         0.0695 1.61e6
 9       18  1856 James Buch‚Ä¶ Dem.       0.588       0.453         0.122  1.84e6
10       19  1860 Abraham Li‚Ä¶ Rep.       0.594       0.396         0.101  1.86e6
# ‚Ñπ 39 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 11 more variables: margin <int>, runner_up <chr>, ru_part <chr>,
#   turnout_pct <dbl>, winner_lname <chr>, winner_label <chr>, ru_lname <chr>,
#   ru_label <chr>, two_term <lgl>, ec_votes <dbl>, ec_denom <dbl>


We start with ggplot():

ggplot()








Tell it what data we are plotting:

ggplot(data = elections_historic)








Map the x and y-axis within aes():

ggplot(data = elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct))








Add a point geometry:

ggplot(data = elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct)) + geom_point()








Go back and map color and shape aesthetics:

ggplot(data = elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct,
                               color = win_party, shape = two_term)) + geom_point()








Add labels by mapping the label aesthetic and adding a geom_text geometry:

ggplot(data = elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct,
                               color = win_party, shape = two_term,
                               label = winner_label)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text()








Here‚Äôs the final code, all put together, changing the axis titles using labs():

# load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(socviz)

# make plot
ggplot(elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct, color = win_party,
                               shape = two_term, label = winner_label)) +
  geom_point() + geom_text() + labs(x = "Percent of popular vote",
                                    y = "Percent of Electoral College vote",
                                    title = "Presidential Elections (1824-2016)",
                                    color = NULL, size = NULL)










Here‚Äôs some other stuff I‚Äôm adding to make this graph better (that you‚Äôre not responsible for):

# load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(socviz)
library(ggrepel)

ggplot(elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct,
                               color = win_party, shape = two_term,
                               label = winner_label)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text_repel() +
  labs(x = "Percent of popular vote",
                                    y = "Percent of Electoral College vote",
                                    title = "Presidential Elections (1824-2016)",
                                    color = NULL, size = NULL) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(yellow, red, blue, "gray")) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, size = 1.4, color = "gray80") +
    geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, size = 1.4, color = "gray80") +  theme(legend.position = "none")

Code
# libraries
library(tidyverse)

# plot
ggplot(elections_historic, aes(x = popular_pct, y = ec_pct, label = winner_label,
    color = win_party, shape = two_term, label = winner_label)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5,
    size = 1.4, color = "gray80") + geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, size = 1.4, color = "gray80") +
    geom_point() + geom_text_repel() + labs(x = "Percent of popular vote", y = "Percent of Electoral College vote",
    title = "Presidential Elections: Popular & Electoral College Margins", subtitle = "1824-2016",
    color = NULL, size = NULL) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
    scale_color_manual(values = c(yellow, red, blue, "gray")) + theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Data wrangling I
text:
What is data-wrangling?


‚Ä¶the process of transforming and mapping data from one ‚Äúraw‚Äù data form into another format with the intent of making it more appropriate and valuable for a variety of downstream purposes such as analytics‚Ä¶ Data analysts typically spend the majority of their time in the process of data wrangling compared to the actual analysis of the data. ‚Äì Wikipedia



Most of your time working with data will be spent wrangling it into a usable form for analysis

title: Data wrangling I
Data wrangling I
text:
What are pipes?



Pipes link data to functions
They look like this %>%, or |>
Definitely use keyboard shortcuts

OSX: Cmd + Shift + M
Windows: Ctrl + Shift + M

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Why pipes?

With pipes: üòç

penguins %>%
    filter(species == "Adelie") %>%
    mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g/1000) %>%
    select(body_mass_kg)



Without pipes: ü§¢

select(mutate(filter(penguins, species == "Adelie"), body_mass_kg = body_mass_g/1000),
    body_mass_kg)




Both produce the same output, but pipes make code more legible

title: Data wrangling I
Data wrangling I
text:
Our first wrangling function: filter()

filter() subsets data objects based on rules












baby_subset <- babynames %>%
    filter(name == "Angel")

Subset babynames to only babies named Angel

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Why filter?

Lots of real-world applications: finding flights, addresses, IDs, etc.


Sometimes we want to focus on a specific subset of data: the South, Latin America, etc.


Useful to deal with common problems: outliers, missing data, strange responses

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC)


Third largest welfare program in the US
Only people who meet certain criteria receive it
Effects of program and its design are hotly debated

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Using filter()
To use filter(), we need to tell R which observations we want to include (or exclude) using rules



gap_africa = gapminder |>
    filter(region == "Africa")

Rule: return all observations from gapminder where the region variable is equal to ‚ÄúAfrica‚Äù

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Making the rules: logical operators



Rules filter data based on whether variables meet certain criteria
Rules rely on logical operators:

Equal to, not equal to, less than, more than, included in, etc.
Observations that meet the rule are returned; those that are not are dropped

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The logical operators



Logical operators.


Operator
meaning




==
equal to


!=
not equal to


>
greater than


<
less than


>=
greater than or equal to


<=
less than or equal to


&
AND (both conditions true)


|
OR (either condition is true)






Why double equal sign?

text:
Using filter()

Apples

apples

  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Gala         green      4 TRUE

4 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Green apples

apples |>
    filter(color == "green")

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name      color pounds sweet
  <chr>     <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Gala      green      4 TRUE

Notice words are in quotations!


Notice that the number of rows has decreased: 2 x 4

title: Data wrangling I
Data wrangling I

Apples that aren‚Äôt green

apples |>
    filter(color != "green")

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE


The ! symbol negates: not equal to

title: Data wrangling I
section: At least 4 pounds but less than 6

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Combinations: The OR (|) operator
‚ÄúObservations where either this is true OR that is true‚Äù

Apples that are red OR green

apples |>
    filter(color == "red" | color == "green")

# A tibble: 4 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Gala         green      4 TRUE 
3 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
4 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE








Note


The | should be above your Return/Enter key

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Combinations: the AND operator (&)
The & operator can be used to combine rules

Returns observations where both rules are true


‚ÄúApples that are red AND sweet or green AND sour‚Äù:



apples |>
    filter(color == "red" & sweet == TRUE | color == "green" & sweet == FALSE)

title: Data wrangling I
section: What can I filter for? the distinct() function
text:
What can I filter for? the distinct() function
To subset your data, you need to know what values your variables can take; what are the continents in gapminder?

distinct() returns the unique values of a variable

gapminder |>
    distinct(continent)

# A tibble: 5 √ó 1
  continent
  <fct>    
1 Asia     
2 Europe   
3 Africa   
4 Americas 
5 Oceania  




I can then use this information to filter my data:

gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "Americas")

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The last step: creating objects
Step 1-2: the data, the pipe, the wrangling functions

apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)



Step 3: store the subsetted data as a new object for later use

green_apples = apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Objects
In programming, objects can be used to store all sorts of stuff for later use

data, functions, values


We create objects using = or <-


Like this:

new_object = stuff |>
    filter(year == 1999)



Or like this:

new_object <- stuff |>
    filter(year == 1999)

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Naming objects

There are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things. ‚Äì Phil Karlton


Recommend: keep it short, easy to type, informative, and use _ to separate words



# Good
gap_africa = gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "Africa")

# Bad
Countries_In_Africa_That_I_Want_To_Look_Up = gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "Africa")



I use the excellent Tidyverse syntax guide in my work

title: Data wrangling I
text:
Failure to object
Without objects, your work washes away, like tears in the rain



Here, we store our data wrangling


green_apples = apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)

green_apples

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
2 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE




Here we didn‚Äôt store


apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
2 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE

apples

# A tibble: 4 √ó 4
  name         color pounds sweet
  <chr>        <chr>  <dbl> <lgl>
1 Fuji         red        2 TRUE 
2 Gala         green      4 TRUE 
3 Macintosh    green      8 FALSE
4 Granny Smith red        3 FALSE







Notice the original apples remains unchanged!

title: Data wrangling I
text:
The formula
Wrangle the data until you‚Äôre satisfied with the output:

apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)


Store the output as a new object:

sour_apples = apples |>
    filter(sweet == FALSE)



Use the new object (e.g., plotting):

ggplot(sour_apples, aes(x = name, y = pounds)) + geom_col()

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Using objects

What if I wanted to make this same plot, but only looking at countries in Asia?

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Subset to Asia
I can use filter() to subset the data to Asia, store it as a new object gap_asia, and use that new object to make a plot


gap_asia = gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "Asia")

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Using the new object
Notice how I need to use the new object
the original gapminder does not have what I want




ggplot(gap_asia, aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)) + geom_point()












ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp)) + geom_point()

title: Data wrangling II
text:
filter() and variables types
Filtering requires knowing the type of variable you are working with

Numerical variables do not use quotes

gapminder |>
    filter(year > 2000)



Categorical variables use quotes, and spelling must be exact
‚úÖ

gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "Asia")



‚ùå

gapminder |>
    filter(continent == "asia")

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Normalizing variables
To compare across cities we need to take into account differences in population

We want to know how many murders have taken place (or drug overdoses, or crimes, or COVID cases, or‚Ä¶) per person in the city (per capita)


This is called normalizing a variable; changing it so that we can make units more comparable

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Murder rate
In math terms this is just dividing the number of murders by population:
\(Murders_{capita} = \frac{Murders}{Population}\) = ‚Äúhow many murders per person‚Äù


Since this fraction is tiny, the convention is to multiply by a number that makes sense


for the population of a city, say 100,000 people


\(Murders_{per 100k} = \frac{Murders}{Population} \times 100,000\) = ‚Äúhow many murders per 100,000 people‚Äù

title: Data wrangling II
text:
Comparing murder rates
If we look at murder rates, the picture changes:

title: Relationships I
text:
Data, objects, variables
A common source of confusion is giving a new variable the same name as the data object

Here, imports_gdp is an object that contains a variable that‚Äôs also named imports_gdp

imports_gdp = trade |>
    mutate(imports_gdp = imports/gdp)



Don‚Äôt do this! It‚Äôs confusing and can lead to errors

title: Data wrangling II
text:
A common mistake
Say we wanted to multiply GDP per capita by population and plot the result:

gap_gdp = gapminder |>
    mutate(gdp = gdpPercap * pop)


‚ùå

ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = year, y = gap_gdp)) + geom_point()

Mistake: using the original gapminder data, treating gap_gdp as a variable


‚úÖ

ggplot(gap_gdp, aes(x = year, y = gdp)) + geom_point()

Correct: use the new data object, which contains the newly created variable gdp

title: Relationships I
text:
Summarizing data

Often, with data, we want to compare things


Are democracies more peaceful than autocracies?


Does early-voting increase turnout?


To do this, we often rely on statistical summaries of our data:


Means, medians, minimums, maximums, variances

title: Relationships I
text:
Summary stats

The mean: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) \(\frac{(3 + 4 + 8)}{3} = 5\)


The median: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 4


The minimum: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 3


The maximum: 3, 4, 8 \(\rightarrow\) 8

title: Relationships I
text:
Example: an experiment
Some counties let people vote early; others don‚Äôt

Do counties with early provisions have higher turnout?

title: Relationships I
text:
Mean vs.¬†median
We almost always compare averages, but medians are helpful in some cases:











What‚Äôs happening here?

title: Relationships I
text:
One more stat: variation

Another way to compare data is by how much a variable varies


Some distributions are very narrow, others are very wide


Narrow = observations are similar; wide = observations are not similar

title: Relationships I
text:
Measuring variation: the standard deviation
The formula:
\[ s = \sqrt{\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{i=1}^N (x_i - \overline{x})^2}\]

All the movement is here, the sum of the differences between each observation \(x_i\) and the average observation \(\overline{x}\)
\[\sum_{i=1}^N (x_i - \overline{x})^2\]

title: Relationships I

Measuring variation
Same average (~$50,000), different standard deviations


What could we measure with sd? Can we use standard deviation to measure equality?

text:
Using summarize()

gapminder %>%
    filter(year == 2007) %>%
    summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_life
     <dbl>
1     67.0


Notice how the data has been summarized: only one row

Notice that I‚Äôve named the summary statistic avg_life

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the median life expectancy?


gapminder %>%
    filter(year == 2007) %>%
    summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), med_life = median(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
  avg_life med_life
     <dbl>    <dbl>
1     67.0     71.9


Notice! how similar this looks to mutate()

title: Relationships I

Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the min and max life expectancy?


gapminder %>%
    filter(year == 2007) %>%
    summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), med_life = median(lifeExp), min_life = min(lifeExp),
        max_life = max(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 4
  avg_life med_life min_life max_life
     <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1     67.0     71.9     39.6     82.6

Using summarize()
What if I also wanted to know the standard deviation of life expectancy?


gapminder %>%

    summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), med_life = median(lifeExp), min_life = min(lifeExp),
        max_life = max(lifeExp), sd_life = sd(lifeExp))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
  avg_life med_life min_life max_life sd_life

title: Relationships I
text:
Using summarize()

gapminder %>%
    filter(year == 2007) %>%
    summarize(avg_life = mean(lifeExp), med_life = median(lifeExp), min_life = min(lifeExp),
        max_life = max(lifeExp), sd_life = sd(lifeExp))


summarize() is like mutate() in that you are creating new variables


So note that you have to name the new variables!

title: Relationships I
text:
Summarizing with missing data
If you try to summarize data that has missing values, R will return NA:


pokemon %>%
    summarise(average_height = mean(height_m))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1             NA










Note


Any math operation with NA will return NA (.e.g, 3 + NA = NA)

title: Relationships I
text:
What to do?

There are whole classes on what to do with missing data (impute, simulate, model, etc.)


In this class we will tell R to ignore missing observations


We can do this by adding the na.rm = TRUE argument to summary

pokemon %>%
    summarise(average_height = mean(height_m, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1           1.16

title: Relationships I
text:
Remember‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre trying to calculate a summary statistic and keep getting NA‚Ä¶


99.99999% of the time you need to add na.rm = TRUE to your function!



pokemon %>%
    summarise(average_height = mean(height_m, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  average_height
           <dbl>
1           1.16

üö® Your turn: üö¢ trade üö¢ üö®
Using the trade dataset:

How has Inter-Governmental Organizations (IGOs) membership expanded over time?

Calculate the median number of IGOs that countries belonged to in 1960.
Repeat for 2010. About how much has IGO membership grown in 50 years?

What is having a sea border worth?

title: Relationships I
text:
Relationships

summarize() lets us calculate statistics for the whole dataset


But what if we want to do this for different groups within the data?


This is at the heart of making comparisons

title: Relationships I
section: Variation in trade over time: the brutal way
text:
Variation in trade over time: the brutal way
How much do country imports vary for each country over time?

Tedious approach: filter() to country 1, then calculate standard deviation of imports


Starting with China

trade %>%
    filter(country == "China") %>%
    summarise(var_trade = sd(imports, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  var_trade
      <dbl>
1   659178.

text:

trade %>%
    filter(country == "Nepal") %>%

Using the therm dataset:

title: Relationships I
section: How Americans feel about different groups
text:
How Americans feel about different groups


Code
therm_long = therm %>%
    filter(party_id %in% c("Democrat", "Republican")) %>%
    pivot_longer(cols = contains("ft_"), names_to = "group", values_to = "thermometer",
        names_pattern = "ft_?(.*)") %>%
    group_by(party_id, group) %>%
    summarise(avg = mean(thermometer, na.rm = TRUE))


ggplot(therm_long, aes(x = group, y = avg, color = party_id)) + geom_point(size = 2,
    alpha = 0.7) + coord_flip() + theme_bw(base_family = "Fira Sans", base_size = 14) +
    labs(x = NULL, y = "Average thermometer rating (%)", color = "Party self-ID:") +
    scale_color_manual(values = c("blue", "red")) + theme(legend.position = "top")









Note


You‚Äôre not responsible for this graph

title: Relationships I
text:
Math in R
For reference, the math operations:



Math symbols in R


keyboard
operation
example




-
Minus
mutate(profit = gross - budget)


+
Plus
mutate(total = part1 + part2)


/
Divide
mutate(gdp_capita = gdp / capita)


*
Multiply
mutate(gdp = gdp_capita * population)


^
Raise to power
mutate(age_2 = age^2)

title: Relationships II
text:
üå°Ô∏è ugly prejudice üå°Ô∏è üö®

Researchers use feeling thermometers to measure how people feel about different groups


üå° goes from zero (strong dislike) to 100 (strong like)

what does it mean?

title: Relationships II
text:
How do Americans feel about‚Ä¶
The police?

therm |> 
  summarise(avg_police = mean(ft_police, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_police
       <dbl>
1       75.7



Unions?

therm |> 
  summarise(avg_unions = mean(ft_unions, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_unions
       <dbl>
1       53.4

title: Relationships II
text:
Making comparisons
We can compare which groups are viewed more (or less) favorably:

therm %>% 
  summarise(avg_police = mean(ft_police, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_muslim = mean(ft_muslim, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_white = mean(ft_white, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_immig = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_fem = mean(ft_fem, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_black = mean(ft_black, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# A tibble: 1 √ó 6
  avg_police avg_muslim avg_white avg_immig avg_fem avg_black
       <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
1       75.7       50.0      76.1      61.9    52.1      71.3

title: Relationships II
text:
The partisan breakdown
We can look for patterns by using group_by() to separate average support by respondent characteristics:

How do partisans feel about each group?

therm %>% 
  # grouped summaries
  group_by(party_id) %>% 
  summarise(avg_police = mean(ft_police, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_muslim = mean(ft_muslim, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_white = mean(ft_white, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_immig = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_fem = mean(ft_fem, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_black = mean(ft_black, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 5 √ó 7
  party_id    avg_police avg_muslim avg_white avg_immig avg_fem avg_black
  <fct>            <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
1 Democrat          67.8       64.6      74.1      71.7    73.9      78.3
2 Republican        87.6       33.3      81.7      50.2    30.3      65.6
3 Independent       74.2       49.0      74.1      61.5    48.3      69.1
4 Other             72.7       45.1      71.1      65.4    40.7      70.2
5 Not sure          70.1       47.1      70.8      56.9    54.0      66.7



take code and iteratively change it

title: Relationships II
text:
Breaking down support
We can use filter() to focus our comparison on fewer party ID categories:


therm_by_party = therm %>% 
  # look only at Democrats and Republicans
  filter(party_id == "Democrat" | party_id == "Republican") %>% 
  # grouped summaries
  group_by(party_id) %>% 
  summarise(avg_police = mean(ft_police, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_muslim = mean(ft_muslim, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_white = mean(ft_white, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_immig = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_fem = mean(ft_fem, na.rm = TRUE), 
            avg_black = mean(ft_black, na.rm = TRUE))
therm_by_party

# A tibble: 2 √ó 7
  party_id   avg_police avg_muslim avg_white avg_immig avg_fem avg_black
  <fct>           <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
1 Democrat         67.8       64.6      74.1      71.7    73.9      78.3
2 Republican       87.6       33.3      81.7      50.2    30.3      65.6



Where are the biggest partisan gaps? What‚Äôs going on with immigrants? Is this really an apples-to-apples comparison?

title: Relationships II
text:
The immigration gap

What explains this gap? How much is it about each party‚Äôs ideology and how much is about who is in each party?


Immigrants in the USA are more likely to identify as Democrat


Could it be that the big gap we see is all because immigrants are both more likely to be Democrats and have more positive views of own community?


One test: compare non-migrants in each party to see if the gap persists

title: Relationships II
section: Making sense of the immigration gap
text:
Making sense of the immigration gap
We want an apples to apples comparison: White Dems vs.¬†White Reps, Asian Dems vs.¬†Asian Reps, and so on

We can ‚Äútest‚Äù this concern by breaking the data down further, by race:



therm %>% 
  filter(party_id == "Democrat" | party_id == "Republican") %>% 
  group_by(party_id, race) %>%
  summarise(avg_imm = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 14 √ó 3
# Groups:   party_id [2]
   party_id   race            avg_imm
   <fct>      <fct>             <dbl>
 1 Democrat   White              71.2
 2 Democrat   Black              71.1
 3 Democrat   Hispanic           76.2
 4 Democrat   Asian              75.5
 5 Democrat   Native American    62.9
 6 Democrat   Mixed              74.6
 7 Democrat   Other              84.1
 8 Republican White              49.8
 9 Republican Black              54.6
10 Republican Hispanic           58.0
11 Republican Asian              54.7
12 Republican Native American    47.4
13 Republican Mixed              51.4
14 Republican Other              42.3

title: Relationships II
section: Making sense of the immigration gap
text:
Making sense of the immigration gap
We can filter to focus on fewer races:


therm %>% 
  filter(party_id == "Democrat" | party_id == "Republican") %>% 
  filter(race %in% c("White", "Black", "Hispanic", "Asian")) |> 
  group_by(party_id, race) %>%
  summarise(avg_imm = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 8 √ó 3
# Groups:   party_id [2]
  party_id   race     avg_imm
  <fct>      <fct>      <dbl>
1 Democrat   White       71.2
2 Democrat   Black       71.1
3 Democrat   Hispanic    76.2
4 Democrat   Asian       75.5
5 Republican White       49.8
6 Republican Black       54.6
7 Republican Hispanic    58.0
8 Republican Asian       54.7

title: Relationships II
text:
Visualizing the pattern
We can create a new object to make a nice plot:

therm_party_immig = therm %>% 
  filter(party_id == "Democrat" | party_id == "Republican") %>% 
  filter(race %in% c("White", "Black", "Hispanic", "Asian")) |> 
  group_by(party_id, race) %>%
  summarise(avg_imm = mean(ft_immig, na.rm = TRUE))

title: Relationships II
text:
The immigration attitudes gap


Code
ggplot(therm_party_immig, aes(y = avg_imm, 
                              x = race, fill = party_id)) + 
  geom_col(position = "dodge") + 
  labs(x = "Respondent race", y = "Average thermometer level\nfor immigrants", 
       fill = "Respondent race:") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none") + 
  geom_label(aes(label = party_id), position = position_dodge(1), color = "white") + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(blue, red))




comparing apples to apples, the gap persists

Non-differences can be surprsing too

text: Negative polarization

title: Relationships II
text:
Dummy variables
Often, categorical variables are coded 0/1 to represent ‚Äúyes/no‚Äù or ‚Äúpresence/absence‚Äù




sample from leaders dataset

combat

mil_service is a dummy variable: 1 if leader has military service, 0 otherwise; combat is the same but for combat experience

title: Relationships II
text:
Dummy proportions
Dummy variables are useful for lots of reasons

One is that when you take the average of a dummy variable you get a proportion


Coffee today? 1, 0, 0, 0, 1


Average of coffee = \(\frac{1 + 0 + 0 + 0 + 1}{5} = .40\)


We can think about that proportion as a probability or likelihood


What is the probability a random student in class has had coffee? 2/5 = 40%

title: Relationships II
text:
Dummy variables
When you take the average of a dummy variable you get a proportion:

leader %>% 
  summarise(combat = mean(combat, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  combat
   <dbl>
1  0.246


Approximately 24% of world leaders have combat experience, or

there‚Äôs a 24% chance a randomly selected leader has combat experience

title: Relationships II
text:
Dummy variables
Like with anything else, we can take averages by groups

For example, combat experience by country



leader %>% 
  group_by(country) %>%
  summarise(combat = mean(combat, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 189 √ó 2
   country combat
   <chr>    <dbl>
 1 AFG      0.479

title: Relationships
Relationships
Modeling I
text:
Patterns in the data



So far: wrangling and visualizing data
Looking for patterns (hopefully real)
Examples?

title: Modeling I
text:
Patterns and correlations

A useful way to talk about these patterns is in terms of correlations

When we see a pattern between two (or more) variables, we say they are correlated; when we don‚Äôt see one, we say they are uncorrelated


Correlations can be strong or weak, positive or negative

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlations: strength
When two variables ‚Äúmove together‚Äù, the correlation is strong
When they don‚Äôt ‚Äúmove together‚Äù, the correlation is weak

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlations: strength
Better heuristic: knowing about one variable tells you something about the other



Strong: if you know how a county voted in 2012, you have a good guess for 2016
Weak: if you know a county‚Äôs average commute time, you know almost nothing about how it votes

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlation: strength
We also talk (informally) about correlations that include categorical variables
Big gaps between groups \(\rightarrow\) correlated

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlation: direction
‚ûï: When two variables move ‚Äúin the same direction‚Äù
‚ûñ: When two variables move ‚Äúin opposite directions‚Äù

title: Modeling I
text:
Quantifying correlation
When the two variables are continuous, we can quantify the correlation
\[r =
  \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y}) }{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]

Correlation coefficient, r:
ranges from -1 to 1,
perfectly correlated = 1 or -1,
perfectly uncorrelated = 0


All of the movement is here: \(\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})\)

title: Modeling I
text:
Quantifying correlation

\(\ age_{i} - \overline{age}\)

Lots of big, positive products \(\rightarrow\) strong positive correlation


Lots of big, negative products \(\rightarrow\) strong negative correlation


A mix of positive and negative products \(\rightarrow\) weak correlation

title: Modeling I
text:
Interpreting the coefficient







Correlation coefficient
Rough meaning




+/- 0.1 - 0.3
Modest


+/- 0.3 - 0.5
Moderate


+/- 0.5 - 0.8
Strong


+/- 0.8 - 0.9
Very strong

title: Modeling I
text:
Correlation coefficient: just a number

It‚Äôs useful in a narrow range of situations


The underlying concepts are more broadly applicable








Strength
Direction
Meaning

Positive
As X goes up, Y goes up *a lot*


Strong
Negative
As X goes up, Y goes down *a lot*


Weak
Positve
As X goes up, Y goes up *a little*


Weak
Negative
As X goes up, Y goes down *a little*

title: Modeling I
text:
üö® Our turn: correlations üö®
What do these pair-wise correlations from elections tell us?

title: Modeling I
text:
Models



Models are everywhere in social science (and industry)
Beneath what ads you see, movie recs, election forecasts, social science research \(\rightarrow\) a model
In the social sciences, we use models to describe how an outcome changes in response to a treatment

title: Modeling I
text:
The moving parts



The things we want to study in the social sciences are complex
Why do people vote? We can think of lots of factors that go into this decision
Voted = Age + Interest in politics + Free time + Social networks + . . .
Models break up (decompose) the variance in an outcome into a set of explanatory variables

title: Modeling I
text:
Speaking the language






Y
X




Outcome variable
Treatment variable


Response variable
Explanatory variable


Dependent variable
Independent variable


What is being changed
What is causing the change in Y








Maybe you‚Äôve seen some of these terms before; here‚Äôs what we will use

title: Modeling I
text:
Model cars
Say we want to model how changing a car‚Äôs weight (treatment) affects its fuel efficiency (outcome)

title: Modeling I
text:
Modeling weight and fuel efficiency
Very strong, negative correlation (r = -.9)

title: Modeling I
text:
Why a model?

Graph + correlation just gives us direction and strength of relationship


What if we wanted to know what fuel efficiency to expect if a car weighs 3 tons, or 6.2?

title: Modeling I
text:
Lines as models

There‚Äôs many ways to model relationships between variables


A simple model is a line that ‚Äúfits‚Äù the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù


The line of best fit describes how fuel efficiency changes as weight changes

title: Modeling I
text:
Strength of relationship
The slope of the line quantifies the strength of the relationship

Slope: -5.3 \(\rightarrow\) for every ton of weight you add to a car, you lose 5 miles per gallon

title: Modeling I
text:
Guessing where there‚Äôs no data
Line also gives us ‚Äúbest guess‚Äù for the fuel efficiency of a car with a given weight

even where we have no data


best guess for 4.5 ton car \(\rightarrow\) 13 mpg

title: Modeling I
text:
Drawing lines in R
We can add a trend-line to a graph using geom_smooth(method = "lm")


ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Modeling I
section: Where does this line come from?
text:
Where does this line come from?



6th grade algebra notation:
\(Y = b + mx\)
Y = a number
x = a number
m = the slope \(\frac{rise}{run}\)
b = the intercept



Statistical notation:
\(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_{1} x\)
\(Y\) = a number
\(x1\) = a number
\(\beta_1\) = the slope \(\frac{rise}{run}\)
\(\beta_0\) = the intercept




If you know \(\beta_0\) (intercept) and \(\beta_1\) (slope) you can draw a line

title: Modeling I
text: Some lines

title: Modeling I
text:
Which line to draw?
We could draw many lines through this data; which is ‚Äúbest‚Äù?

title: Modeling I
text:
Drawing the line
We need to find the intercept (\(\beta_0\)) and slope (\(\beta_1\)) that will ‚Äúfit‚Äù the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù
\(mpg_{i} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight_{i}\)

title: Modeling I
section: What does it mean to ‚Äúfit well‚Äù?
text:
What does it mean to ‚Äúfit well‚Äù?



Models use a rule for defining what it means to fit the data ‚Äúwell‚Äù
This rule is called a loss function
Different models use different loss functions
We‚Äôll look at the most popular modeling approach:
ordinary least squares (OLS)

title: Modeling I
text:
The loss function for OLS

The loss function for OLS (roughly!) says:


a line fits the data well if the sum of all the squared distances between the line and each data point is as small as possible


\(Y_i\) is the data point \(\rightarrow\) value of observation \(i\) \(\rightarrow\) the mpg of car \(i\)


\(\widehat{Y_i}\) is the line \(\rightarrow\) the mpg our line predicts for a car with that weight \(\rightarrow\)


\(\beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight\)


Distance between each point and line = \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})\)

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(Y_i\) = actual MPG for the Toyota Corolla

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(\widehat{Y_i}\) = our model‚Äôs predicted MPG (\(\beta_0\) + \(\beta_1 \times weight\)) for the Corolla

title: Modeling I
section: Distance between each point and the line
text:
Distance between each point and the line
\(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i}\) = the distance between the data point and the line

title: Modeling I
text:
Back to the loss function
\(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i}\) is the distance between the point and the line

OLS uses the squared distances: \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2\)


The sum of the squared distances: \(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2}\)


Remember that \(\widehat{Y_i} = \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight\)


So can rewrite: \(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2} = \sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight)^2}\)


So we need to pick \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) to make this as small as possible (minimize):
\(\sum_i^n{(Y_i - \widehat{\beta_0} + \widehat{\beta_{1}} \times weight)^2}\)

title: Modeling I
text:
Estimating the parameters

How do we find the specific \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that minimize the loss function?


Zooming out (not just OLS): in modeling there are two kinds of approaches





Statistical theory: make some assumptions and use math to find \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)



Computational: make some assumptions and use brute force smart guessing to find \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)





Sometimes (1) and (2) will produce the same answer; other times only (1) or (2) is possible

title: Modeling I
text:
Computational approach
Imagine an algorithm that:

Draws a line through the data by picking values of \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)
Sees how far each point is from the line
Sum up all the squared distances for that line (remember OLS calls for squaring!)
Rinse, repeat with a new line


The pair of \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that produce the line with the smallest sum of squared distances is our OLS estimator

title: Modeling I
text:
Strawman comparison
Which line fits the data better? (Duh)

title: Modeling I
text:
First candidate: fit the line
Rough guess: what is \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) here?

title: Modeling I
text:
First candidate: the residuals
How far is each point from the line? This is \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})\)

Also known as the residual \(\approx\) how wrong the line is about each point

Remember, our loss function says that a good line has small \((Y_i - \widehat{Y_i})^2\)

title: Modeling I
text:
The best line

This is what geom_smooth() is doing under-the-hood (sorry)


It‚Äôs using math to figure out which line fits the data best


Conceptual best = the line that is closest to all the points


Math best = the smallest sum of squared residuals

title: Modeling I
section: So who are the winning Betas?
text:
So who are the winning Betas?


\(Y = \beta_0 + \beta1x_1\)
\(mpg = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times weight\)
\(mpg = 37 + -5 \times weight\)

title: Modeling I
section: What does this model get us?
text:
What does this model get us?
\[mpg = 37 + -5weight\]

A lot


We can describe the overall rate of change with the slope


for every ton of weight we add to a car we lose 5 miles per gallon


We can also plug in whatever weight we want and get an estimate


What‚Äôs the fuel efficiency of a car that weighs exactly 2 tons?


\(mpg = 37 + -5 \times weight\)
\(mpg = 37 + -5 \times 2 = 27\)
